div.p: Curus Oteologicus: BEING A Compleat Doctrine OF THE BONES; According to the Newet, and mot Refin'd Notions of ANATOMY.

Shewing their Nature, Subtance, Compoition, manner of Oification, Nourihment, &c. Alo the various ways of their Articulation; together with the Parts to be conider'd in each particular Bone of the whole SKELETON, as Figure, Cavities, Protuberancies, Foramina, Scituation, Connexion and Ue; with everal Curious Obervations relating to the BONES.

To which is Annex'd by way of APPENDIX, An Excellent Method of Whitening, Cleaning, Preparing, and Uniting the Bones, to Form a Movable Skeleton, wherein the Bones may have the ame Motions as in a Living Subject.
The Whole being a Work very Ueful and Neceary for all Students in Phyick and Chirurgery.
By ROBERT BAKER, Chirurgeon.
London, Printed by I. Dawks, for D. Browne, at the Black Swan without Temple-Bar; and R. Clavell, at the Peacock near St. Duntan's Church. 1697.

div.head: INTRODUCTION.
div.p:
REctum et Regulaui, & obliqui, is an undeniable Axiom among the Mathematicians; the ame may be aid of that thrice Noble Science call'd Anatomy, it being the Grand Foundation, or if I may o ay, the Corner-tone both of Phyick and Chirurgery, epecially the latter, it being the Bais on which we build all our Structures towards the Cure of Ditempers, both External, and Internal; for how is it poible we hould pretend to Cure any Internal Affect, unles we know what Part or Vicera is affected; the
like may be aid in Chirurgical Caes; for what Surgeon can give a true Prognotick in Wounds, Vlcers, &c. or Retore Luxated or Fractured Limbs, or perform any Manual Operation, without a true Knowledge of the Oeconomy of Humane Body; and this ought not to be a bare Knowledge only of the Parts, and where they lye (as many who are unwilling to give themelves the Trouble of Scrutinying into the more nice Compoition of them) but we ought alo to know the Figure, Structure, Ve, what Juices they eparate, and the like, all which the Doctrine of Anatomy teaches; for to what a prodigious height is the Art of Medicine improved, ince our mot Ingenious and Accurate Countryman, Doctor Harvey,
found out and demontrated the Circulation of the Blood; Jolivius the Lymphatick Veels; Caper Aellus the Venae Lacteae; and Haver's the Articular Glands; with many more great Improvements, which are too long to mention; nay, the whole Method of Phyick is almot alter'd; and this Great and Noble Work could ne'er have been perform'd, had thoe Learned Men contented themelves with a bare Knowledge o the Parts only; for uppoe any had a Pile of Building to Erect, would they think you, employ any one who is Ignorant of what Figure of Size the Stones or Timber ought to be, and how to be join'd together? The ame may be aid of a Chirurgeon, or Phyician, who is ignorant of Anatomy;
o that whoever is willing to perform the Duty of a Good and Conciencious Surgeon, ought to know the whole Fabrick of Man's Body; and that as well in its perfect, and ound tate, as morbid, that he may re-etablih Health when lot, and retore unound Parts to their former Sanity.

I hall not here Harangue, or run out in the many Praies which are due to Anatomy, or Treat of its Origin and Antiquity; it being already o excellently well perform'd by the Learn'd Doctor Charleton, in the Preface to his Anatomic Prelections, but proceed to the Matter in hand.

Various are the Opinions of Authors, about the Parts we ought to begin with, in Anatomical Demontrations.
Bartholinus ays, We ought to begin with the Teguments, they being firt in view, then proceed to the Vicera, and Mucles, and latly, end with the Bones; and the Reaons he gives for it, are becaue the Bones cannot be examined before they appear, which they cannot do, (ays he) 'till all the Mucles are eparated from them; others begin with the Abdomen, or Lower Belly, o proceed to the Thorax, then to the Head, and latly, to the Extremities; by reaon the Belly is apt to end forth in a little time, very noiom and offenive Smells, which would hinder the Operator from proecuting his intended Deign: 'Tis true this is the bet way, uppoing we have but one Subject to work on,
and that we be obliged to hew all, or mot of the Parts on this one Subject.

p.U: ays we ought to begin with the Bones, and gives many Cogent Reaons to prove it; firt, becaue they erve as Beams or Supporters of the whole Body. Secondly, they erve to faten the Mucles too; for how can we tell the Origin or Inertion of any Mucle, if we be wanting in the true Doctrine of the Bones; nay, all the Parts eem as if deign'd for their ue; for when the Bones ceae to grow, they alo put a Period to the growth of all the other Parts.

ays, that in the Anatomical School of Alexandria, the Young Students in Medicine, always began their
Anatomical Coure with the Oteology, and then proceeded to the Doctrine of the Mucles, everal of which receive their Denominations from the Bones, which they pas by, or lye on, as the Tibialis Poticus, and Anticus the Peronii, Scapulares, Sternohyoidei, Matoideii, &c. Latly, the Knowledge of the Bones is of that great ue to a Surgeon, that it's impoible for him to retore well a Fracture or Dilocation, who is Ignorant of; the Structure, Figure, Articulation, &c. of the Fractured or Dilocated Bone.

div.p: All thee Reaons are a ufficient Inducement to perwade us, that we ought to begin with the Skeleton, and then proceed in order, to the Ret of Man's Body.

The Skeleton is an Aemblage of all the Bones of the Body; it's either Natural, or Artificial; the Natural, is when the Bones are all excarn'd, but kept together by their proper Ligaments; the Artificial one, is when the Bones are Artificially Cleans'd, Whiten'd and Join'd together by Wiers.
That part of Anatomy which Treats of the Bones, is call'd Oteologia, which is as much as to ay, A Dicoure of the Bones.
We hall in this Tract examins what belongs to the Bones in general, and what belongs to each particular; which we hall divide in everal Demontrations.

div.head: Curus Oteologicus: BEING A Compleat Doctrine OF THE BONES, &c
Demontration I.
Of the Bones in General.
div.p:
THE Doctrine of the Bones in General,What to be conider'd in the Bones in General. conits in thee Eleven Things, as Definition, Subtance, Compoition, manner of Oification, Veels, Nourihment, Differences, Parts, or Things to be conider'd in the Bones;
together with their manner of Articulation, Number and Ue; of all which in order.

Galen defin'd a Bone to be the mot hard,Antient Definition. firm, and terretrious part of all the Body. Laurentius adds, and ays, That it's ingendred by the formative Faculty, by reaon of great heat, out of the mot cras and terretrious part of the Semen, to erve as a Foundation to all the Body, and to give it Shape and Figure; but this Definition, as it is not compleat enough, o on the other hand, the word Faculty, is a Term which they ued to expree themelves by, when they were at a los for an Anwer or Solution to any Quetion propoed; beides, it's not at all agreeable to the Idea we have of the formation of the Bones, or Ue; yet it's certain the Antients made ue of that Term to explain mot of the Actions of the Body; for when they were to declare how the Chyle, or Blood was made, or how the Bones or Cartilages were form'd, nay, how the Senes acted; they anwer'd, That the Stomach had
a Chylific Faculty, the Liver a Sanguifying; the Bones were form'd by an Oific, and the Cartilages by a Cartilaginous Faculty, that the Eye aw by the Viive Faculty; &c ic de caeteris.

This was a general Anwer, by which they eluded (as well by their occult Qualities) all Difficulties propoed to them, o that their Pupils were as Ignorant at the finihing of their Studies as at the beginning; but we at this Day explain all thee Actions purely Mechanically; as I hall hew in demontrating each part of the Oteology exactly, that the Action which it performs, abolutely depends on its Structure, o that it can do nought ele, but what it does.

But to return from whence I have digres'd;Modern Definition. the Moderns ay a Bone is a imiler part, mot dry, cold and hard, without ene, (unles by ome Preternatural Accident) inflexible, affording Stabiliment, Figure and Form to the whole Body.
A Bone may be conider'd at two ditinct times, either before or after the Birth.

In their beginning,Nature and Subtance. or before the Birth, they are of a Membranous Subtance, wrapt up, as it were, in very many folds, or Laminae; which at firt are Gelatinous, in time grow Cartilaginous, and at lat when ufficiently indurated by the Oific Liquor, are o trong as to reit all inward force, and their Parts which had before ome Heterogeneous Bodies in their Intertices, being queezed cloer by the power and preure of the Spirits, di-engage themelves from thoe Bodies which lye between their Laminae, o grow more olid, wholly fixt, and void of motion, which is about the time when the Bones have attain'd their full perfection of growth, which alo puts a period to the bulk and magnitude of the Body, o that they are no more extended or enlarged, either in breadth or length.

The Bones are compoed of many trings,Compoition of tringy Fibrils. or threads, which have their
coure according to the length of the Bones, or their Figure; for if the Bone be of an unequal, or irregular Figure, the trings are alo unequal, and irregular; except in the Cranium, where the threads begin at a point, (ometimes two or more) for the mot part in the Centre, and terminate in the Circumference of the Bone, as the Spokes in a Wheel; for which reaon it's more thick, and compact there, than in the Circumference, the thready Fibrils being more cloe and united there, which is viible in the Cranium of a Foetus; the Bones have alo ome tranvere Fibres, to hold the long ones in; which may be een in the Bones of the Tarus, as alo in the Extremities of mot of the long Bones, where the Poroities are.

The Oification begins not in the ame place of every Bone;Where the Oification begins. in the long Bones it begins in the middle, and towards each end; but in Bones of an irregular Figure in everal places, as may be een in the Oa Innominata of a Foetus, where it begins at three points or places at once, o that they
eem to be three ditinct Bones united jut in the middle of the Acetabulum, but in time, as the Oification increaes, they grow more trong, the fibrous threads join, and o make but one Bone; for if the Bones hould have been totally Oified before the Birth,Why the Bones are not totally Oified before the Birth. how hould the Foetus pas through the Vagina of the Womb as it doth? For it's without Dipute, that both the Bones of the Head, and alo the Hips of the Foetus, give way omewhat in time of Excluion; for it's oberved that thoe Animals which have long and mall Heads, but big Bodies, have the Bones of their Head wholly Oified before the Birth, but their Ribs not, o careful is Nature in this Affair.

In the Skull, and mot broad thin Bones, as the Sternon, the Oification begins at two, three, or more points, commonly about the Centre; Nature is alo very cautious in Oifying long Bones all at once; for if their Extremities had been Oified as oon as their middle, the ligamentous and tendorous threads would not enter
o eaily their ends, to join them together, which they can do, being not totally Oified. The Oification, as I aid afore of the Oa Innominata, begins at three points, that they may have the greater olidity; but quite contrary in the Bones of the Cranium, for while the middle of mot Bones of the Cranium are fully Oified, their edges are only Membranous, that they may give way omewhat in time of Birth, which they would not, were the Cranium compleatly Oified. Thee are the Reaons why Nature retards Oification in ome Bones, and advances it in others.

The Bones before they be throughly indurated,Veels. have many Blood-veels, which are obliterated, as oon as the Meduller Glands are large enough to eparate the Oily Particles from the Arterial Blood, (which have a Property of keeping the Bones oft) then the Oific Liquor which is emitted from the aforeaid Glands hardens them, and o prees the Parts cloer together, and hinders the Blood from paing and repaing as uual, when
they were ofter, their bony threads gave way, and being then not pret o cloe; which Veels are alo bonified by the Oific Juice, having lot their firt ue; yet ome few remain, which erve only the Meduller Glands, for their Nourihment, the Pulation of Blood in them having trength enough to catter the Fibrils of the Bones in that Part, and o makes paages for themelves.

The Bones are nourihed two ways,Nourihment two fold. the one in their beginning, that is, when they are only Membranous, and is quite different from the Nourihment they receive after their Perfection; for now they are nourihed as all other Membranes,When Membranous. with Blood immediately from the Arteries, o that if you then cut them, you'll find every thread bloody, which is not o when truly Oified; for when the Bones have occaion of greater olidity, Nature then changes her way of Nourihment,When Bony. which is by a peculiar Liquor of a Saline Tartarous Nature, prepared by the Meduller Glands, the more oily Particles being eparated,
and kept in them,Medulla Quid. which is that we call the Marrow; this Liquor; I ay, ininuates its elf all along the bony trings, and is viible in a Fractured Bone, it appearing at their Extremities, and meeting together caues them to reunite,Callus Quid. which we call Callus; nay, we often find that the adjacent Parts are ometimes indurated by this Oific Liquor, and the Limbs often grow Gouty, and has not its former nimble motion, the Callus growing too big; for if they were bloody Particles, which exuded forth of their bony threads, intead of generating a Callus, it would Impotumate, for all Blood hed out of its Veels putrifies, this Liquor is of uch an indurating Quality, that if the Fibrils of the Bones be any ways broken, that it heds it elf in any great quantity, it will Oifie the very Tendons; I have een the Marrow it elf turn'd bony.

The Bones have Nerves (is plain) although no Sene,Nerves, but no Sene. for when they come to the olid Subtance of the Bone, they are pret o cloe, that the Animal Spirits cannot enter their Subtance,
and o conequently can have no feeling,Acids often the Bones. unles oftned by Acids, which will caue them to have a dull Sene, as may be try'd by the ue of Acids on the Teeth; which, as the acidity goes off, reaume their former hardnes, and inenibility. Sometimes the Blood acquires uch an acidity which is apt to caue a Spina Ventoa, Caue of a Spina Ventoa.
which is nothing ele but a Carioity of the Bones, proceeding from an Acid Blood coming to the Meduller Glands for the Nourihment of the Bones; alo Acid Acrid Humours in an Ulcer may caue a Carioity.
The Differences oberved in the Bones,Differences Nine. may be derived from Nine Things, viz. from their Subtance, Quantity, Figure, Situation, Ues, Motion, Senibility, Generation, and Cavities.

The Firt Difference is derived from their Subtance,From their Subtance. for ome Bones have a very hard one, as the Tibia; others les hard, as the Vertebrae; and finally, others have a more oft and pongy one, as the Sternon.
The Second is derived from their Quantity,From their Quantity. for ome as thoe of the Thigh, Leg, Arm, &c. others les, as thoe of the Head; ome leat of all, as thoe of the Fingers.

The Third proceeds from their Figure; ome are long,From their Figure. as the Os Femoris, Tibia, &c. others hort, as thoe of the Fingers, and Metatarus, &c. ome round, as the Rotula; others flat, as the Oa Palati; others quare, as the Oa Parietaria; others triangular, as the firt Bone of the Sternon, Scapula, &c.

The Fourth is from their Situation, From their Situation. as ome are plac'd in the Head, others in the Trunk, and ome in the Extremities; others are eated deeply, as the Officles in the Cavity of the Ear, &c.

The Fifth is from their Ue,From their Ve. as ome erve to utain the Body, as thoe of Legs and Thighs, others to contain and defend the Parts, as the Ribs defend the Lungs, Heart, &c. Oa Innominata, and Os Sacrum, the Bladder, Womb in Women, &c. Cranium the Brain.

The Sixth is known by their Motion;From their Motion. for ome have a more manifet motion, as the great Bones of the Extremities; others have a les, as thoe of Tarus and Carpus; others none at all, as thoe of the Head.

The Seventh is from their Sene,From their Sene. which is eaily remarkt, for all the Bones, generally peaking, have no Sene, except the Teeth, and they only a very dull Sene; except, as I have already oberved, they be oftned by ome offending Acid.

The Eighth is taken from the time of their perfect Generation,From the time of their Generation. and Perfection; for ome Bones are perfect in the Womb, or before the Birth, as the mall Officles of the Ears; and others, which do not acquire their Perfection, but as the Subject advances in Age, as all the ret of the Bones of the Body, yet ome of thee Oifie quicker, as thoe of the lower Jaw; others lower, as the Fontanella of the Head.

The Ninth and lat Difference is drawn from their Cavities,From their Cavities. for ome have great ones, and contain Marrow,
as the Bones of the Extremities; and there be others which have no manifet Cavity, but only Poroities; which contain a Meduller Juice, as thoe of Tarus, Carpus, &c. ome have holes, by which Veels pas and repas, as thoe in the Bais of the Cranium and Vertebrae; others have only Trenches or Furrows, as thoe of the Sternon, Ribs; others have Sinees, as the Os Frontis, and Oa Petroa; latly, ome are pierced like the holes in a Seive, as the Os Cibriforme.
The things to be conider'd in the Doctrine of each Bone are three;Threetian's conider'd in the Bones. 1. The Apophiis. 2. Epiphiis. And 3. Cavities, Furrows, and Sinues.

Firt,Apophyis, of Proces. The Bones not being of one even Form, or Figure, have at their Extremities everal Prominencies, or Protuberancies, which are of two orts, the one is a continued part of the Bone jetting manifetly out, above its uperficies, ordain'd for the more commodious and trong inertion of
the Tendons of the Mucles, and is call'd an Apophyis, or Proces.

The Second is an additional Bone growing to another by immediate contiguity,Epiphyis, or Apendage. as if Nature had forgot to make the Bone long enough, and is generally more porous than the Bone it elf; which will eparate if you boil in Oil, for they will not eparate if boil'd in Water never o long, unles the Subject be very young, it's call'd an Apendage, or Epiphiis; this in young Bodies may ometimes by great force be eparated from the ret of the Bone, or to peak improperly, Dilocated.

If this Protuberance be round, it's call'd Caput, under which is the Cervix, as in the uperior part of the Os Femoris; if it be flat, Cordilus; if harp, Corone; others from their figure are call'd Styloides, Motoides, Coracoides, Ancyroides, &c.
Embrions have not thee Protuberances o large; for except ome very few large ones, they are hardly viible.
Thee Protuberances are either Natural, as the Spina of the Scapula; the ret are only Accidental.

The Accidental Protuberances of the Bones,Caue of the Protuberances. (which are only manifet when the Bones are perfect) are caued by the Tendons of the Mucles or Ligaments, which always are inerted there; for the tringy Filaments of the Tendons and Ligaments, entring into the Bones (while oft) between their tringy threads, caue them to inlarge there into a bulk, which it mut do of neceity, there being a double portion of Fibres united together; which are all Oified as the bony Liquor increaes.

It's a general Note, that where you find uch Protuberances, ome Ligaments or Tendons of Mucles are inerted there; although thee Protuberances eem only to be accidental,Ves of the Protuberances. yet they have many ues; firt, by them the Mucles have a greater force to lift or pull up the Part. Secondly, they are of ue to inlarge the Extremities of the Bones, that the Body be utain'd.

The next part of the Bones,Cavities of three orts. that come under our Conideration, are the Cavities, which are either External or Internal: Thee Cavities are of three orts, Holes, or Foramina; Trenches, or Furrows, and Sinues.

A Foramina, Foramina, or holes. or Hole, is a Cavity which is perforated in a Bone, or made up of two Bones join'd together, as may be een in the Bais of the Cranium, lower Jaw, Vertebrae of the Ribs. They are deign'd for the paage of the Veels and Nerves, which pas through them, alo the great Cavity of the Ichium may be call'd a Hole.

A Trench, Trenches, or Furrows. or Furrow, is not a Cavity through the Bone, but only a deep hole, or hollownes, long, or round, as the orbit of the Eye, &c. ometimes very hallow, as thoe in the inide of the Cranium, &c. ome of a mean between both, as thoe in the Joints, to receive the Protube. rances of other Bones; ome call thee Sinues, but improperly.

A Sinus is a ort of Cavity in a Bone,Sinues. whereof the Orifice or Entrance is very
trait, and the bottom large, uch are in the Frontal Bone, &c.
I hall declare the ue of all thee Cavities, when I Treat of each Bone in particular.

All the long Bones of the Body are hollow in the inide towards the middle,All long Bones hollow. and contain a Marrow, which is only a heap of Membranous Veicule, full of a fatty or oily Subtance, call'd Meduller Glands; which,Meduller Glands. as I oberved before, eparated the more oily Particles from the Blood, o that the more alfih only remain'd, which has the Oific Virtue of rendering the Bones hard: The Ends or Extremities are porous, omewhat like a Pumice Stone, containing a Meduller Juice,Meduller Juice. like thin Oil, and have very few Glands; it's probable that the Ligamentous trings entring the top of the Bones, divide and catter the bony threads, which make it o porous.
The External Superficies of all Bones have a certain olid Cortex. Solid Cortex in all Bones.

All the External Cavities which erve for Articulation, have at their Circumference an Eminence call'd a
Lip, to which is fatned a Circular Ligament, which embracing the Head of the received Bone, fortifies the Articulation.
As for each particular Proces and Cavity, we hall decribe them in the Demontrations of each particular Bone.
Before I mention the Articulation of the Bones, I think it convenient to oberve thee things.

Firt,The Bones not of the ame bignes in Women as in Men. All the Bones are not of the ame greatnes, and that not only in Perons of different Stature, but alo in thoe of an equal Height, or Stature; for ome of thee have their Bones maller than others, and it's Beauty conits (as ome have aid it does) in the delicatenes and mallnes of the Bones, then Women have all the Reaon imaginable to have a better Shape and Symetry than Men, by reaon their Bones are maller; the Bones alo of their Face are finer and more mooth.

There's alo a great difference between the Bones of the Oa Innominata, Difference of the Oa innominata.
which makes the Pelvis. In Men they are les and more unequal, but in Women larger, and moother, to have a greater pace to contain the Womb; alo a Woman's Os Sacrum inclines more backwards than a Man's which makes their Buttocks more large.

We mut alo oberve a difference in the Bones,Difference of the Bones according to Age. according as we grow in Years; for from the Birth to the twentieth Year, or thereabouts, the Bones continually increae, and from that to the ixtieth they continue in the ame tay, neither increaing or diminihing; but after that they daily diminih, by reaon of the bony Fibres drying, approach nearer one another, and o mut conequently have a les bulk.

The Colour of the Bones is not alike in all;Difference from the Colour. for ome have them very white, others les, but ome almot greyih; o that if you take the ame Pains in whitening two or three Skeletons, yet one will be doubtles whiter than the other.

It's true,Periotion. as I have oberved before, that the Bones have no ene; yet they are Inveted with a very enible Membrane, call'd Periotion, as if we hould ay a Membrane over or invering the Bone, it's very thin; all Bones have this, except the Teeth. I think there's a great Quetion about its Ue.Ve. Some affirm it's to convey bloody Veels to the Bones; but its rather believed to be for the greater implantation of the Tendons of the Mucles; for when you eparate the Periostion, the Mucle comes off with it.

I hall now proceed to the manner of the Articulation of the Bones; there's uch Art in the Conjunctions of the Bones,Articulation of the Bones. that they have erved as a pattern to many Artizans in their Curious Works; for they could find nothing in Nature more fit to copy by; and although there be o many various ways of Articulation, as almot Junctures, yet they are all neceary, otherwie Man could never move himelf every way o compleatly as he does.
The Bones join'd together have either motion, or none, the former is call'd Articulation, the latter Symphyis, Or growing together.
Articulation,Articulation twofold. is either for manifet, or obcure motion: The firt is call'd Diarthrois, or looe Articulation, the other Synarthrois, or more cloe and compact.

Diarthrois is Threefold, 1. Enarthrois. 1. Diarthrois threefold.
2. Anthrodiae. 3. Gynglimus.
1. Enarthrois, Enarthrois. is when a large Head is received into a deep Cavity, as the Os Femoris in the Acetabulum of the Oa Innominata.

2. Arthrodia, Arthrodia. is when the Cavity is hallow, and the Head of the received Bone alo hallow and flattih, as the Os Humeri, with the Scapula, and the Bones of the Metacarp and Metatare; with the firt Phalanx of the Fingers and Toes.

Now the Bones which are Articulated by Enarthrois, and Arthrodia, are capable of all orts of motion, as upwards, downwards, forwards,
backwards, and circularly; yet the deeper the Cavity, and the more bony the Edges are, the motion is render'd more low, and not o brisk and nimble as when the Cup is not o deep;Thee two all orts of motion. this is een in the Os Femoris, and Acetabulum, for the Os Humeri being inerted in a more hallow Cup, is capable of all orts of motion, and that to a great degree, yet about the Cup or the Scapula there are everal Cartilages, which make it eem as deep as the Acetabulum, but at the ame time by giving way, hinders not the very free motion of the Humerus.
Ginglimus, Ginglimus threefold. is when the ame Bone both receives, and is received, and is Threefold. 1. Ginglimus Proximus. 2. Longus. 3. Compoitus.
1. Ginglimus Proximus, Proximus. is when a Bone is received by another, and receives the ame, as the lower part of the Os Humeri, and lna.

2. Ginglimus Longus, is when two Bones are join'd together according to their length,Longus. o that the one Bone having a Cavity in its ide towards the
end, receives the head of the other, which has a Cavity likewie at its other Extremity, to receive a Protuberance of the firt Bone, as the Radius and Ulna.

2. Ginglimus Compoitus, Compoitus. is when a Bone receives one, and is received by another, as in ome of the Vertebrae of the Back, where one receives the upper, and is received by the lower: Ginglimus Compoitus, is alo when a long Proces of a Bone is inerted into another above it, and o turns in the Cavity as an Axis in a Wheel, as the econd Vertebra of the Neck with the firt.

As Enarthrois, and Arthrodia, Ginglimus for Flexion and Extenion ouly. erve for all orts of motion, Ginglimus erves only for Flexion, and Extenion; yet in the Radius and Vlna it erves for Pronation and Supination.
When a Bone is join'd by double Arthrodia, it makes a ort of Ginglimus, as may be een in the lower Jaw.

Synarthrois, Synarthrois. or obcure motion, is in the Ribs which have a little motion in their ends towards the Vertebrae in
Repiration; alo mot of the Bones of the Tarus and Carpus, which in great preure give way a little, for the more eaie motion of the Part.
Symphyis, 2. Symphyis Threefold. is only when the Bones are united without any motion at all, and is Threefold, as Sutura, Harmonia, and Gomphois.
1. Sutura, Sutura. is when the Bones are united together in their edges by little Points, or Teeth (as it were) unequally, as may be een in the Bones of the Cranium.

2. Harmonia, Harmonia. is an union of the Bones by a imple Line only, either treight or curved, as the Bones of the Noe, Face, Palate; but this is only in their outward part, for we always find them Internally Serratil, or Suture like.
3. Gomphois, Gomphois. is when one Bone is fatned in another, as a Nail in Wood, o are the Teeth in the Jaws.
Some add to the symphyis everal other orts of Articulations, as Synchondrois, Syarcois, yneurois, vel Syntenois.

Synchondrois, Synchondrois. is when a Cartilaginous Subtance interveens, as may be een in the middle of the lower Jaw; which in young are two ditinct Bones, but as the Oific Liquor predominates, grow one; alo the Oa Pubis are united by it, o are the Bodies of the Vertebrae one to another.
Syarcois, Syarcois. is when a Bone is fatned by Means of Fleh only, as the Os Hyoides in the Mouth, and the Scapula to the Ribs.
Syneurois, Syneurois. vel Syntenois, is when Bones are united together by means of Ligamentous Parts, as the Rotula with the Bones of the Legs; but I think thee are not properly Articulations.

The Bones of the Body in an Adult,Number 245. are accounted 245. For Example, the Head has 64, the Trunk 57, the Arms and Hands 64, the Legs, &c. 60, which makes in all 243. Some perhaps may wonder why the Great Creator compoed uch a number of Bones; I Anwer, how could the Hand or Arm perform all the Actions it does, and put it elf in o many Thouand
Potures, had it not many Junctures and Articulations? For had the Part been compos'd but of one or two Bones, how Lame and Prepoterouly would it have acted? The ame may be aid of the Legs, &c. And if the Spine had not been made up of uch a number of Vertebrae, how could we have bent, or mov'd it as we do? It was therefore convenient and neceary for the Perfection of Man and his Functions, to have as many Bones as he has.

The Head,Head 64. as I aid, is made up of 64 Bones, which are thus number'd, 6 proper of the Skull, 8 of the Ears, 4 in each, 3 Common of the Skull; Face 11, with the Vomer; Os Hyoid 1, lower Jaw 1, though ome make it 2, Teeth about 32, which make 62; but if you add the Oa Spongioa, they make 64.

The Trunk conits of 57 Bones;Trunk 57. Vertebrae 25, as 7 of the Neck, 12 of the Back, 5 in the Loins, and 1 in the Os Sacrum, which ome ay is made up of 5; 3 in the Coccyx, Ribs 24, Sternon 3, Oa Innominata 2, which

The upper Extremities, or Limbs, conit of 64 Bones,Vpper Limbs 64. taking in the Claviculae, which I think we ought to do, ince much of the motion of the Arms depends on them; there's 32 Bones in each Arm then, as Clavicula, Scapula, Os Humerus, Radius, and Vlna; 8 Bones of the Carpus, 4 of the Metacarp; and Bones of the Fingers 15, 3 in each, accounting the Thumb as one Finger, which added to the other Arm makes 64.

The Lower Extremities conits of 60,Lower Limbs 60. that is, 30 in each; as the Os Femoris, Rotula, Tibia, and Fibula; 7 in the Tarus, 5 in the Metatarus, and 14 in the Toes, which makes together with the other Leg 60.

Some augment the number, who make many of the Os Hyoides, 3 of the Os Innominatum, 2 of the lower Jaw, 5 of the Os Sacrum, and add the Oa Seamoidea, which are not often found, and then for the mot part in the great Toes, which would then make up above 250.
I am come now to the lat Conideration of the Bones in General,Ve of the Bones. which is their Ue.

They have many Ues; 1. They erve for the upport of the Body, being as o many Beams or Pillars in a Houe. 2. For the Defence of ome Noble Part, as the Skull for the Brain, Ribs for the Heart, Lungs, &c. Oa Innominata and Sacrum, which make the Pelvis for the Womb, Bladder, &c. 3. For the Progreion and Motion of the Animal, of which with the Mucles, they are the only Intruments. 4. To give Shape and Figure to the whole Body; thee are the General Ues, as for their Particular, we hall peak of them in the Demontration of each particular Part.

div.head: Demontration II.
Of the Bones of the Skull.
div.p: WE now come to the Doctrine of the Bones in particular;Skeleton divided into three parts. we divide the Skeleton into three parts, as the Head, Trunk and Limbs.

By the Head we undertand not only all the Bones of the Skull, but alo thoe of the Face, even from the Vertix to the firt Vertebra of the Neck; by the Trunk all that compoes the Neck, Back, Loins, Os Sacrum, Oa Innominata, Sternon, &c. By the Limbs thoe which make up the Arms and Legs, generally o called; of all which in order. The Head is ubdivided into the Skull, properly o called, and the Face.

The Skull (I mean that upper part whoe Bones compoe,Figure of the Skull. and make up a large Cavity, which contains the Brain, in which you mut conider its Figure altogether) is globous, omewhat
what long, but flattih towards the ides, for the better Situation of the Temporal Mucles; which being on, make it look more round.

All the Bones of the Skull are made up of two Laminae or Plates,Skull, two Tables. call'd Tables, one Internal, the other External, between which lyes a Medullar Juice, of a reddih Colour, call'd the Pith,Diploe, what. or Diploe, which is very dicernable in young Perons; but as we grow in Years, the Oific Liquor invading, it bonifies.

The Exterior and Superior Superficies of the Cranium; is very mooth, and polihed, having few inequalities; but where the Sutures are, the Internal Superior Superficies is not o equal, having many little Sulci, or Furrows, which are caued by the Veels of the Dura Mater, when the Skull is but Membranous, being then capable of receiving any Impreion, that the Pulation of the Veels give it,Caue of the Furrows. o make themelves Furrows; but its Internal Inferior Part is very unequal, by reaon of the many Productions and Cavities found there.

The Cranium has many Foramina, Foramina in General.
which give way or paage to the Veels els paing and repaing, which fill up thee holes o cloe, that no Fumes or Vapours, as the Antients believed, can get in, or come forth, unles by the Veels themelves: we will hew all thee holes, at the latter end of this Demontration.

It's a Quetion,The bignes of the Cranium, depends on the Brain. whether it be the Cranium, which gives greatnes to the Brain; or whether the Brain gives form to the Cranium, I Anwer, that the bignes of the Cranium depends on that of the Brain, for two Reaons; Firt, the Cranium, while Membranous, epecially towards the Sutures, extends it elf more or les, as the Brain increaes: The Second, is that the Cranium is not totally Oified till the Brain is arrived to its full Magnitude; for we ee in an Infant new-born, that although the Brain be perfect, yet at the ame time, the Cranium is only Cartilaginous about the Sutures; though bony in the middle of every Bone, nay, the Fontanella does not Oifie under ome Years; from whence
alo it is, that in Labour thee Bones, as I have before oberved, give way, and fold over one another, for the more eaie exit of the Infant out of the Womb.
The Bones of the Cranium are join'd together by Sutures,Sutures, twofold. which are of two orts, true, or fale; or to peak more properly, common, or proper.
The Proper are Eight.Proper, three.

1. Coronalis, Coronalis. (vel Frontalis) becaue the Antients ued to wear their Garlands on that part of the Head, it reaches from one Temporal Bone to the other, joining the Os Frontis to the Oa Parietaria.

2. Lambdoides being like the Greek Letter < in non-Latin alphabet > ,Lambdoides. others call it Triangularis; this Suture is eldom wanting, whatever the ret are; it begins at the Bais of the Os Occipitis, and acends obliquely to the middle of the back-part of the Head, and decends again to the other ide of the Head; the Point in the middle is call'd Vertix, Vertix, what. by reaon the Hair on the Scalp commonly turns there; it joins the Occipital Bone
to the Bones of the Temples, and Oa Parietaria.

3. Sagittalis, Sagittalis. becaue it runs lengthways as an Arrow; it begins at the Vertix of the Sutura Lambdoides, and marching trait forwards to the middle of the Coronal Suture; in Children it divides the Coronal Bone, and goes quite to the Noe, which as we grow in Years vanihes; yet I have een it in the Cranium of ome Adults.
The Sutures being o united together, make up a Figure almot like this )<.
Some of our Modern Anatomical Profeors, will have the Sutures to be Serratil only in the Superior Table, but join'd by Harmony in the Lower, but it's always found to the contrary.

The Common are Five,Common, five. or more; thee are the Chief, 1. The Suture Squamoe, Squamoae. or Scale-like, becaue apply'd as one Scale on another; they are two, one on each ide, which arie from the outide of the Matoidproces, and circumcribing the Temple-bones,
decend Circularly towards the Bais of the Ears.
Whatever Anatomits ay, I think them true Sutures, being Serratil as well Internally, as Externally.

2. Orbalis, Orbalis. it begins at the top of the Sutura Squamoa, and decending obliquely towards the Orbit of the Eye, croes on the top of the Noe, o paes over the other Eye, and o on to the other Squamous Suture.
3. Naalis, Naalis. which divides the Bones of the Noe.
4. Sutura Bailaris, Bailaris. which eparates the other Bones from the Os Bailare.
5. Sutura Ethmoides, Ethmoides eu Cribriformis, dividing this Bone from the Os Frontis; ome ay that thee Four lat are rather Harmonia, than Sutura, but Demontration hews the contrary.

The Sutures have many ues,Ve of the Sutures. the principal are thee; 1. Many Ligamentous Fibres pas through them from the Dura Mater to the Pericranium, which upends the Dura Mater, o are a ort of hinderance of too violent Concuions of the Brain, in any great motions of the Body; for by
thee Fibres the Brain is kept more light; it's by this Communication, that when the Pericranium is wounded, an Inflammation often aries in the Dura, Mater, as if it had received ome offence it elf: Thee Fibres alo, by upending the Dura Mater, and keeping it cloe to the Interior Surface of the Cranium, the Arteries in the Cortical part have a freer motion, which would be omewhat impeded, if it fell on the Brain. 2. They give paage to everal Veels, that are paing and repaing to the Diploe, for the Nourihment of the Bones of the Cranium. 3. They are of ue in hindering Fractures from paing further than one Bone, for they always top at the Sutures, which if the Skull were but one continued Bone, the Fracture would be apt to run over all the Cranium, as may be een daily in any Earthen or Glas Veel, when crackt by a troke, it commonly runs almot quite over, or round. Some ay, a fourth Ue is, to give a vent or breathing to many Fuliginous Vapours gather'd within the Cranium, but I much
quetion this ue; yet ome ay, that many who have had their Sutures too cloe, have been ubject to inupportable Head-aches, Tranpiration having been topt, as they ay; but I rather think it proceeded from the preure of the Veels which pas through them, which cauing an Obtruction of the flowing Liquors, was a caue of thee Pains.

There are many Obervations in everal Authentick and Learned Authors,Some have had no Sutures. of ome who have had none, or very few Sutures, and others who have had more than uual. I aw a Skull lately in the Hands of an Ingenious Chirurgeon, my very good Friend, which had a Suture running tranvere the Occipital Bone, and the Sagittal pas'd quite through the Os Frontis, and it was the Skull of an Adult; uch is the various Diports of Nature; alo in very Old Age the Sutures are almot obliterated, the Oific Liquor then predominating.

Embryons have no Sutures,How the Sutures are made. or at leat not to be well ditinguihed, their Skulls being wholly Membranous; o
while the Oific Liquor, (which as I have aid, begins at a point, &c. in the Cranium) ininuates it elf along the bony Threads, and by degrees hardens them, ome Fibrous and Vacular Strings paing from the Dura Mater to the Pericranium, hinders in thoe places the bony Liquor from uniting, o forms thee Seams or Sutures; for in a Foetus the Skull being as yet Membranous in its edges, wrap, or fold themelves as it were one over another, to take up les room in the Birth; for had the Skull been totally Oified before the Birth, the Infant would for the mot part endanger the Life of the Mother; this may be daily een in young Children, where the Skull is wholly Membranous in the top of the Head between the Coronal and Sagittal Sutures, which place is call'd Fontanella. Fontanella, what.
The Bones of the Skull are either Proper or Common; the Proper are Six in number.

1. The Os Frontis, Proper Bones of the Skull, Six. or Coronalis, the Forechead-Bone; of a Semicircular Figure,
in its uperior part, ituated in the Superior part of the Face, and Anterior of the Cranium, bounded above by the Coronal Suture from the Oa Parietaria, on the ides by the Oa Temporum, below by the Tranveralis, or Orbalis from the Noe, Eyes, &c.
The things to be conider'd in this Bone, are its Cavities and Procees.
Its outide is mooth, as are mot of the Bones of the Cranium, no Tendons or Ligaments being inerted here.
In its lower part over each Eye is a mall Foramen, Foramine. through which paes a Branch of the five pair of Nerves to the Muculous Fleh on the Forehead.

It has Four Procees;Procees. the two greater at the Internal Canthus of the Eyes, the other two at the les; its inner Lamen about the Eye-brows towards the Noe, bunches inwards, o caues a hollownes there, which is part of the Sinus Frontalis.

2. The Os Occipitis is oppoite to the Coronal,2. Os Occipitis. in the hinder part of the
Head, it's the thicket and tronget Bone of the Head; the reaon whereof is this, we having no Eyes behind, Nature has framed it of a thicker conitence, to the end it may the better reit any troak or blow it receives; it's five-corner'd, join'd to the Oa Parietaria by the Lambdoid Suture, and to the Oa Temporum by the Squamous Sutures, and it's bottom to the Os Sphenoides, by a ort of Harmony.
The things to be conider'd in this Bone, are its Sinues, Foramina, and Procees.

Its Sinues,Sinues, or Sulci. or rather Sulci, are many, two on the External part jut behind the Foramen Medullare; and even in the Internal Superficies, the two larget of which contain the Protuberances of the Carebel, the other are of mall moment.

It has five Foramina or Holes,Foramina. the lowet and larget call'd Foramen Medullare, the Spinal Marrow paing by this hole to all the Vertebrae; the other four are les, and only erve for the exit of the Veels; two give paage
to the Nerves of the Tongue, and two to the Arteriae Cervicales; thee are proper Foramina, there are two others which are common both to it and the other Bones, one on each ide the Os Petroum, which give paage to the eighth pair of Nerves call'd parvagum, and to the two Internal Jugular Veins.

It has five Procees, four of which are on the outide by the Foramen Medullare; the two innermot are call'd Condyli, Procees. and are received by the two hallow Sinus's of the firt Vertebra of the Neck, erving for the Articulation of the Head; in its Internal part it has a long Protuberance or Ridge, which acends in the middle from the Foramen Medullare, and parts the Protuberances of the Cerebellum, this is its fifth Proces.

There's another mall Protuberance or Proces,A ixth Proces, not decrib'd by any Author. which is not decrib'd by any Author; it lyes between the Condyli, from it paes a Ligament, which joins it to the firt Vertebra of the Neck.
It has alo everal mall Prominences towards its Bais on the outide, ome Tendons being inerted there.

Third and fourth are the Oa Sincipitis, vel Parietaria, Third and fourth, Oa Sincipitis. becaue alike, or forming the Walls of the Cranium, as it were; they are the thinnet Bones of the Head, are join'd by the Coronal Suture to the Os Frontis, to the Occiput by the Lambdoidal, to the Oa Temporum by the Squamoae, and to one another by the Sagittalis: They are very mooth on their outide, but omewhat unequal within,Sulci. having many mall Sulci, or Furrows, for the reception of the Veels of the Dura Mater; they are thinnet towards the Sutures, as are all Bones of the Cranium; thee Furrows are thus caus'd,How caus'd. while the Skull is Membranous, the Veels by their Pulation make themelves thee Furrows.
Thee Bones are of a Quadrangular Figure.Figure.
Anatomits call that the Bregma of the Head,Bregma, what. where thee two Bones are united together by the Sagittal Suture, towards the Coronal Bone.

The fifth and ixth Bones are call'd Oa Temporum, Fifth and ixth, Oa Temporum. o call'd a Temporibus, becaue as a Man grows old, the Hairs on the Temples whiten the oonet; they lye on the ides of the Skull, being join'd above by the Squamous Sutures to the Oa Parietaria, before to the Proces of the firt Bone of the upper Jaw, below to the Sphenoidal Bone, and behind to the Os Occipitis; their uperior part is mooth, thin, and emicircular, o ometimes call'd Oa Squamoa; Oa Squamoa & Petroa. Sinues. their inferior thick, and hard, and call'd Oa Petroa.
Their Parts to be conider'd, are Sinues, Procees, and Holes.

Thee Bones have two Sinues each; the firt is large, and lin'd with a Cartilaginous Subtance, plac'd between he Meatus Auditorius, and its long Proces, which makes up part of the Os Jugale, Glenoides. call'd Sinus Glenoides, and receives one of the Procees of the lower Jaw, call'd Condylus; the other two are les, and lye on the inide of the aforeaid long Proces.
Each Bone has four Procees,Procees. three External, and one Internal.

The Firt is call'd Styloides, Styloides. being lender, harp, and long; ome take it to be an Appendix only; in Infants it's Cartilaginous; thoe Animals which want thee Procees, their Os Hyoides have a double Horn, or Proces which upplies its place, many Mucles arie from it.
Secondly,Matoides. Matoideus, or Mamillaris, becaue like a Cow's Teat; 'tis blunt, thick, and hort, hollow within, plac'd at the botton of the Auditory paage.

Thirdly,Jugalis. Proceus Jugalis vel Zygomaticus, very long, omewhat broad, and curved, it's thin, ariing a little from the outide of the Sinus Glenoides, and meeting with another long Proces belonging to the firt Bone of the Maxilla uperior, are join'd together by an oblique Suture, and make up the Os Jugale, or Bridge.

Fourthly, The Internal Protuberance is call'd Petrous, Petrous. from its hardnes, or Auditorius; it's omewhat long, and jets out towards the inner Bais of the Skull, or Os Sphenoides; it's hollow, and contains the Intruments
of Hearing:Four mall Bones of the Ear. It has four little Bones within its Cavity.
1. Incus, or the Anvil.
2. Malleus, the Hammer.
3. Stapes, the Stirrup.
4. Os Orbiculare, which lyes jut on the top of the Stapes.

Thee Bones are as big and perfect at the Birth, as in Adults; they are Articulated after this manner,Manner of Connexion. the Apophiis of the Malleus is fatned to the Tympanum, and Articulated by its Head in the Cavity of the Incus; this Incus has two Feet, the hortet of which is plac'd on the Tympanum, and the longer on the Stapes, on which lyes the Os Orbiculare.
Thee Bones have many Foramina each.Foramina.
The Firt is External, and call'd Foramen Auditorium, eu Meatus Auditorius, Meatus Auditorius. by which the Sound enters to the Organs of Hearing.
Its Second, Is narrow, hort, and oblique, by which the Jugular Vein enters the inner Cavity of this paage.
The Third, Is between the Styloid and Matoid Proces, and ends in that which goes from the Ear to the Mouth.
The common Bones are three.Common Bones, three.

1. Os Sphenoides, Os Sphenoides. Bailare, vel Cuneiforme, ome call it Polyforme, from its trange Figure; it's not call'd Cuneiforme, as if it were like a Wedge, but by reaon it's eated between the Bones of the Skull and upper Jaw; in Infants it conits of two or three Bones; it's very thick at its Bais, but thin towards the Temples. It's join'd to, or touches all the Bones almot of the Cranium, and ome of the Bones of the upper Jaw, to which it's fatned by the Sphenoid Suture.
Its Parts to be conider'd, are either Procees, Sinues, or Foramina.
It has eight Procees,Procees. four Internal, and four External.

The Internal are call'd Clinoides, Clinoides. they reembling the Feet of a Bed; thee with the depret Sinus in the middle,Sella Turcica. make up the Sella Turcica, being like the Seat of a War-addle, on
which lyes the Glandula Pituitaria.
Two of the External are call'd Pterigoidei, Pterigoidei. eu Aliformes, or the Bats Wings, being like the Wings of a Bat; the other two have no Name.

The Sinues are many.Sinues. It has one in each Proces, call'd Pteregoides, Pteregoides. to give way to the Muculi Pteregoidei Interni: It has alo a very large one in the middle of the Sella Turcica, to receive the Glandula Pituitaria.
Within this Bone lyes a true Sinus, Bailaris. call'd Bailaris, which have the ame Glands, and eparate the ame Juice, as the Sinus Frontalis, and has the ame ue.
The Foramina, Foramina. are either Common, or Proper.

The Common are thoe which lye between it and the Oa Petroa, through which the Jugulars pas; the proper are twelve, ix on each ide; the firt pair is call'd Trancolatores, Trancolatores. which erve as a dicharge to the Glandula Pituitaria; the econd Foramina Optica, Optica. by which paes the Optick Nerves; the third Motoria, Motoria. by which
paes the Motory Nerves; the fourth call'd Crotophites; Crotophites. the fifth Gutatoria, Gutatoria. by which the Tating Nerves pas; the ixth call'd Carotides, Carotides. by which the Carotid Arteries pas.

The econd Common Bone is call'd Os Cribriforme, Os Cribriforme. being perforated like a Seive, the Fibrils of the Olfactory Nerves pas through thee Holes; it's eated at the middle of the Bais of the Forehead, to which it's join'd by Harmonia; it's alo join'd to the two Bones of the upper Jaw, and behind to the Os Sphenoides.

On its inide it has an almot Triangular Proces, call'd Crita Galli Crita Galli. the Coxcomb; it aries jut where the Proces of the Sinus Frontalis ends, and reaches about half way in the middle of the Bone; the Falx which divides the two Lobes of the Brain, is tyed to the point of this Proces.
On its outide,Septum Nai. jut oppoite to the Crita Galli; it has another very thin, but hard Proces, call'd Septum Nai, dividing the Notrils.

To the Os Cribriforme is annex'd two other very fine and thin Bones,Oa Spongioa. one in each Notril, call'd Oa Spongioa, they be wrapt up, as it were, in many folds, and lin'd with a Membrane made up of the Expanded Fibres of the Olfactory Nerves; o that thoe Creatures, who have more of thee Laminae have a more exquiite mell, as Cats, Greyhounds, &c. for a Man has not above three or four folds, whereas the above-nam'd Creatures have very many; o that it's not difficult to judge of the acutenes of the mell, from the multiplicity of thee folds; mot Anatomits conider them as parts of the Os Cribriforme, uing the one for the other promicuouly; but I think them to be different Bones.

The third Common Bone is call'd Os Jugale, Os Jugale. vel Zygoma, by ome the Bridge, or Yoak-bone; it's not one ditinct Bone, but made up of a long Proces of the Temporal Bone, and another of the firt Bone of the upper Jaw.
It's ituated on the outide of the Face,Situation. under the External Canthus of the Eye, there's one on each ide.
Its ue eems as if ordain'd by Nature,Ve. for the defence of the Temporal Mucle which paes under it; it alo gives Origination to the Muculi Maeteres.

div.head: Demontration III.
Of the Bones of the Face.
div.p:
IF the tructure of the Bones of the Cranium be worthy our Admiration, the Compoition of the Bones of the Face, which now comes under our view, is no les urprizing; for although that contains the Brain, which is one of the mot Noble Parts of the Body; yet the Face where mot of the Senes are lodged, and for many Reaons may be call'd the Image of the Soul, ince mot, if not all the Paions of the Mind, are fully demontrated in the Face, cannot merit les, epecially in the wonderful tructure of the Bones which compoe it. The Face is alo the Seat of Beauty, which Charms and Attracts the Eyes of all to behold it;The Bones give Figure, Form, and Beauty to the whole Body. and nothing contributes more to this Beauty than a good Formation, and true Symmetry of the Bones: Ex. gratia, if the lower part
of the Coronal Bone bunch out too much, it makes them Beetle brow'd, as we call it: If the Bones of the Noe be too large, and riing from the Face, it makes them Hawk-noed: If the lower Jaw be too harp, or pointed, it makes an Out mouth, and o of the ret; yet we may ay the ame of the Bones of the whole Body, they giving, as I have aid, Shape and Figure to all; o that if they be any way deform'd or unproportioned, that part mut of neceity be disfigured.
The Bones of the Face are divided into thoe of the upper and lower Jaw.Diviion.
The Bones of the uperior Jaw are eleven in number,Bones of the upper Jaw, eleven. five on each ide, and an odd one.

The Oa Triangulares are big,1, 2, Oa Triangulares. of a hard and olid Subtance, in Figure triangular, wherefore o call'd, plac'd on the lower ide of the outward Canthus of the Eye's Orbit, the middle are advanced out, and riing, which forms the Balls of the Cheeks: One of their Angular Procees, as I aid before, makes up the Os Jugale, being join'd
with the long Proces of the Temple-Bone; they alo make the inferior part of the Orbit of the Eyes, and is united to four Bones, viz. the Coronalis, Sphenoides, Maxillary, and Os Petroum.

They have three Apophies each;Apophiis, three. one of which makes an eminence, which forms the leer Angle of the Eye; the other advancing towards the Noe, makes the greatet part of the inferior Lip of the Orbit; the third may well be call'd Proceus Jugalis, which I have already mentioned.

The Oa Lachrimalia, 3, 4, Oa Lachrimales. eu nguis, are very little and thin, in hape of a Nail of a Man's Hand, eated in the great Canthus of the Eyes, within the Orbit; there's a mall Foramina, in each call'd Lachrimale, in which the Lachrimal Duct paes to the Noe,Puncta Lachrimalia. alo through this hole paes a Branch of the fifth pair of Nerves, to the inner Membrane of the Noe.
Thee Bones are o mall, that they be eaily lot.

The Oa Male 5, 6, Oa Maxillares. ome call them Maxillares, are the thicket, greatet,
and pongiet of all the Bones of the Face, and makes up the greatet part of the Cheeks and Palate.

Parts to be conider'd in thee Bones, are firt, many deep Cavities which are in their lower edge, call'd Alveoli, Alveoli. or Sockets, in which the Teeth are fatned: Secondly, each has an Internal Sinus, which is lin'd with the ame ort of Glandulous Membrane, as the Sinus Frontalis, and of the ame ue, and is call'd Sinus Maxillare. Sinus Maxillare. There's alo another long one, which runs along over the Roots of the Teeth, in which the Veels pas which erve for the Nourihment of the Teeth.

The Oa Nai are two long,7, 8, Oa Nai. hard, and omewhat thick Bones, of a Pyramidal Figure each, being join'd, they make up the bony or uperior part of the Noe; their lower Extrmities are omewhat unequal, for the more trong Connexion of the Cartilages of the Noe with it; they are join'd together by Harmonia.

The lat pair are call'd Oa Palati, 9, 10, Oa Palati. are very broad, but thin, and being join'd by Harmonia, make up the Roof
of the Mouth; they are join'd to the Oa Maxillares forwardly, and backwardly, ideways to the Pterygoid Apophiis, by the Sphenoidal Suture: Each Bone has a hole forwardly, call'd Foramen Gutativum.

The eleventh Bone of the upper Jaw is call'd Vomer, 11, Os Vomer. by reaon the Antients ay it reembes a Plough-hare; it's ituated in the middle over the Palate, edgeways, and is, as it were, a ort of Septum, dividing the interior part of the Notrils.

Before I pas to the lower Jaw,Orbita Occulorum. 'twill not be amis to give a Decription of the Orbits of the Eyes; they are two great Cavities plac'd at the inferior part of the Os Frontis, which erve as Habitations to the Eyes, and to defend them againt all Injuries; their external part is quite round, but internally they grow Pyramidal, having at their bottom many perforations for Veels, &c.
Each Orbit is made up of part of ix different Bones,Each Orbit made up of ix Bones. which altogether compoes its Cavity.

Five of which are Common, and one Proper, which is call'd, as I have already demontrated, Os Vnguis vel Lachrimale: Of the Common, three belong to the Cranium, and two to the Face; the firt of thoe of the Cranium, is the Coronal, which forms the uperior part; the econd is the Ethmoidal Bone, which forms part of the internal ide next the Noe; the third is the Sphenoidal, which makes up part of the internal Cavity; the two of the Face compoe all its lower part, the Os Triangulare forming that part towards the leer Canthus, and the Maxillare, that next the greater.

The lower Jaw is but one continued Bone in Adults,Inferior Jaw. but in young Bodies is compoed of two join'd together in the fore-part, by Syncondrois; they unite, and become one about the eventh Year, of a omewhat Circular Figure, or rather like the Greek Letter , mooth and polihed without, but a little rough within, everal Mucles being inerted, and ariing from thence.
The Parts to be conider'd in this Bone, are its Procees, Foramina, and Alveoli.

It has two large Procees at each end,Procees. the firt call'd Condiloides vel Articularis, Condiloides. it's received into the Sinus of the Os Petroum, and fatned there by a trong Membranous Ligament; the motion of the Jaw depends on this Articulation; the other is call'd Corone, Corone. which from a large Bais ends in a harp point; it lyes under the Os Jugale, the Tendon of the Muculus Temporalis is inerted into it; thee Procees are in the uperior part of the Bone. In its inferior part, jut where it begins to turn up on each ide, are its Angles, to whoe outward part the Maeter Mucles are inerted, and the Pterygoidei to the interior.
This Bone is omewhat hollow within, containing a Meduller Juice.

It has four Foramina, Foramina. two of which are at the Roots of the Procees in the inide, in which a Branch of the fifth
pair of Nerves, together with the anguifying Veels enter, and pas under the Roots of the Teeth, ditributing Branches to each as they pas; the other two are in the fore-part of the Chin, out of which come two Twigs of the aforeaid Nerve, which are pent on the Mucles and Skin of the lower Jaw.Alveoli. It has alo its Alveoli, or Sockets for the Teeth, as the upper Jaw.
The Ues of the lower Jaw,Ves. beides its adding to the Beauty of the Face, is to help Matication, and erves to form the Voice.
The Teeth are the hardet of all the Bones of the Body,Teeth. having a peculiar Cortex, are mooth, and fix'd in the Alveoli of the Jaws, by Gomphois.
They are in number about Thirtytwo,Number 32. of three Ranks or Orders.
1. The Inciores, Inciores 8. or Cutters, four in each Jaw plac'd in the fore-part, and have commonly but one Phang or Root; they are alo call'd by ome Riores, they appearing when we laugh.
2. Canini, Canini 4. or Dog-teeth, by ome the Eye-teeth, two in each Jaw, one on each ide the Inciores; they have ometimes two Roots, but trong, and crooked.
3. The lat are call'd Molares, Molares. or Grinders, in number about twenty, five on each ide the Canini, and have two or three Phangs.

The Teeth are not perfected all at once, nor appear before a certain time, when they force their way through the Jaws and Gums; yet there are Obervations of ome who have been Born with Teeth; the firt that appear in Children, are for the mot part the uperior Inciives, which is ometimes ooner, ometimes later, but generally about the eventh, eighth, or ninth Month; then in time come the Canini, and latly the Molares: When the Teeth come to about the number of twenty, there appears no more till about the eventh Year, about which time there appears four more: At fourteen there comes four more, and towards the twentieth Year the lat four, which are call'd Teeth of
Widom, becaue they come at an Age, when we ought to be Wie and Serious.
The firt twenty Teeth are call'd Milk-teeth, which fall or hed about the eventh Year, and new ones come in their places.
I have een ome who have had new Teeth, when they have been upwards of Sixty Years, but this is not very uual.

The Teeth have everal Ues;Ves. firt, they erve for Matication, which is its chief, the Teeth being as o many Mill tones which bruie and grinde the Aliment, the Inciores cut the Morel, and the Molares grinde it. Secondly, to help Articulation of the Voice, for we ee thoe that loe their Teeth, epecially the Inciores, do not peak plain, but lip, as we call it; they are alo Ornamental.

Since we are demontrating the Bones of the Head,Os Hyoides. it will not be amis to mention the Bone which is at the Root of the Tongue, being united only by Mucles; it's call'd Os Hyoides, or Ypiloides, by reaon it's like the Greek V.
It conits of two parts, the Body and Horns which receive the Epiglottis.

The principal Ue of this Bone,Ve. is not to upport the Tongue, as ome pretend, but rather to facilitate the entrance of Air into the Trachea Arteria, alo of the Aliments into the Oeophagus; many Mucles alo are inerted into this Bone.

The Bones of the Cranium being join'd together, Foramina, in the whole Cranium. there are many Foramina or Holes, through which Veels pas and repas; to begin then in order, thee appear firt, and are commonly by pairs.

1. There's a Hole which lyes between the Crita Galli, Foramen, Crita Galli. and the Proces of the Sinus Frontalis; it's a ingle Hole, and mentioned by no Author as I find: It may well be call'd Foramen Naale, vel Crita Galli; through this Hole a Veel paes from the Sinus Longitudinalis of the Dura Mater to the Noe, where it becomes double, one to each Notril; this is the way how in great Commotions of the Brain,
the Blood ometimes treams out, and that with violence, the Veel being then more turgid.
2. The Foramina in the Cribriforme Bone,Foramina Ethmoides for the paage of the Olfactory Nerves, and may be call'd Foramina Ethmoides.
3. The Foramina Opticorum Nervorum,Foramina Opticorum number two.
4. Two for the Nervi Motorii, Foramina Motorii. and other Veels, they are very large long Holes.
5. Two call'd the Crotophite, Foramina Temp. or Temporal Holes, through which paes two Branches of the fifth pair of Nerves, to the Temples.
6. Two for the Arteriae Carotides, Foramina Carotidum which lye jut by the ides of the lower parts of the Sella Turcica.
7. Two mall ones,Foramina Durae Matris. one on each ide the Carotide Holes, call'd Foramina Durae Matris.
8. Two for the Auditory Nerves,Foramina Auditoria. which pas into the Antra Auditoria.
9. Two for the Jugular Veins.Foramina Jugul.
10. Two call'd Linguales, Foramina Lingnales. through which paes Veels to the Tongue.
11. Two more for the Cervical Arteries,Foramina Nervor. paris 5. and alo for the exit of ome Nerves of the fifth pair.
12. Latly,Foramen Medullare. the great one, call'd Foramen Medullare, for the paage of the Spinal Marrow.
All thee Holes are in the Bais of the Skull, or Internal Part.
There are alo everal Foramina, of great ue in the External Part.
1. Are two Foramina, Foramina Orbicularia. or Holes, one by the edge of the orbit of each Eye, call'd Orbicularia, through which paes a Branch of the fifth pair of Nerves, to the Lips.
2. The Foramina eu puncta Lachrimalia, Foramina Lachrimalia. in the Lachrimal Bones through which the Tears pas into the Noe.
3. The Foramina Palati, Foramina Palati. they are plac'd in the fore-part of the Roof of the Mouth next the Teeth, the thinnet Mucus of the Noe is convey'd through thee two Holes.

4. Two in the back part of the Palate,Foramina Alia. through which Branches of the
fifth pair of Nerves pas to the Palate.
As for the Foramina of the lower Jaw, I have already mentioned them in the Decription of that Bone.

div.head: Demontration IV.
Of the Bones of the Trunk.
div.p: THE next part of the Skeleton that is to be Demontrated,Diviion, threefold. is the Trunk, which we hall divide into Three Parts, as the Back or Spine, Ribs and Breat; and latly, the Hips, or Oa Innominata.

The Back, or rather Spine, is compoed of many Bones, call'd Vertebrae, Vertebrae. or Spondils, all which being join'd or united together, may not unfitly be term'd a Pyramid of Bones; but before we Treat of them in particular, it will be requiite to ay omething of the Spine in General,Of the Spine in General. in which everal Things are to be taken notice of.
1. All the Bones,Denomination. from the firt of the Neck, to the very Extremity of the Coccigis, are call'd the Spine, I uppoe from the acute Procees each Vertebrae have, call'd Spinales.

2. The figure or hape of the Spine,Figure. is of great Conideration, for if you look on its Anterior or Poterior Parts, it appears treight; but if you look on its Lateral Parts, its curved in and out: Firt, the Spondils of the Neck bend inwards, for the better upport of the Oeophagus, alo to utain the Head in an Equilibrium, then the Vertebrae of the Back jet themelves outward, to augment the Capacity of the Thorax, that the Heart and Lungs may have a larger room to play in; towards the Loins again, they bend inwards, not only to defend the great Veels which lye on them, but alo to Counterballance the better the weight of the Body; the Os Sacrum bends outward, that the Pelvis be inlarged to contain the Bladder, Womb in Women, and Intetinum Rectum; and latly, the Os Coccygis bends inwards, that it might not be offended when we it down, alo that the Intetinum Rectum be tyed to it.

The third Thing to be oberved in General,Bodies of the Vertebrae. or Common to all, is that the Bodies, of each Vertebra are of a
pongy Subtance, made up of many irregular bony Threads, containing a Medullar Juice, of a Convex Figure forwards, but Concave backwards, and plain above and below, being only join'd with Cartilages, which makes them Contiguous, & unites them there, which gives them a more eaie motion, the Body alo of each Vertebra gradually increaes in bulk, till to the very Os Sacrum; for it's reaonable that thoe which upport, hould be larger than thoe which are upported, and at the ame time as the Spinalis Medulla paes down it grows les, loing of its bulk as the Nerves pas from it, and the Foramina Medullares of each Vertebra conequently les.

4. Each Vertebra have five Things to be conider'd,Five things to be conider'd in the Vertebra. which belong to all; 1. Each, as I have aid, have a Body. 2. Each have a great Foramina, Foramina Spinales. through which the Spinalis Medulla paes, even to the very Os Sacrum, which may well be call'd Foramina Spinalia vel Medullaria; thee holes are larget in the Vertebrae of the Neck, and o leen as they decend, everal
Nerves, as I have hinted before, paing from the Spinal Marrow, o leens them; but the Bodies grow larger to utain the ret, the Spinal Marrow reaches no further than the lat Vertebra of the Back, where it begins to divide into many mall Filaments, which are ubdivided into maller in the Os Sacrum, Cauda Equina, quid? where it's call'd Cauda Equina, or the Hore-tail. 3. They have each even Procees,Seven Procees in each Vertebra. four oblique ones, two uperior, and two inferior, two tranvere, and an odd one call'd Acutus, vel Spinalus, by ome Poterior. 4. They are join'd one to another in their oblique Procees by Ginglimus, Conjunction. and by Synchondrois in their Bodies; alo on their inide, they are lin'd with a trong mooth Membrane, which reaches from the firt, to the Os Sacrum. 5. They have many Sinuffes, but the mot remarkable, are thoe under their oblique Procees, which being united to others above the aforeaid Procees of other Vertebrae, make certain Foramina, through which the Nerves of the Spinal Marrow paes, as alo many Blood-veels to
and from the Spinalis Medulla; they may be aptly enough call'd Foramina Nervina. Foramina Nervina.

We come now to Treat of each Vertebra in particular;Of the Vertebrae in particular. Number 25. the Vertebrae are in number twenty-five; that is, even of the Neck, twelve of the Back, five of the Loins, and one of the Os Sacrum, to which is annex'd the Oa Coccygis.
The Neck has even.Seven of the Neck.

The firt is call'd Atlas, 1. Atlas. by reaon is utains the Head, as Atlas was uppoed to do the Heavens; its tranvere Procees, as alo all the other of the Neck, are not o long as thoe of the Back; it's Articulated to the Condiloid Procees of the Os Occipitis, by its uperior oblique Procees, in which are two Sinus's that receives the aforeaid Condiloid Procees; this Articulation is a ort of double Arthrodia, o is only capable of Flexion and Extention; it has very little, or no Body, but within has a mall Sinus to receive the Dens of the econd Vertebra; this Sinus is lin'd with a trong Ligament,
which fatens the aforeaid Dens, the Spinal Proces is a very little blunt knob, but all the other Spines of the Neck are forked, except the lat. It has a mall round Proces in its upper part where the Body hould be, from which paes a mall Ligament, to another mall round Proces between the Condiloides of the Occipital Bone, cloe to the Foramen Medullare.

The econd Vertebra is call'd Dentata vel Epitrophous, 2. Dentata. becaue between its two uperior Procees, prings another very hard one, call'd Dens, being like a little Tooth, which being received into the above-mentioned Sinus of the firt Vertebra, and encompaed with trong Membranous Ligaments; this moves in the Atlas as an Axis, as the Flexion and Extention depend on the firt Vertebra with the Head; the Circular Motion depends on this and the firt: When a Luxation happens here, the Neck is aid to be broke.

The five following have no particular Name, and are much like one another, only increaing a little in bignes, and the Spinal Proces of the lat is
not fork'd, beginning to grow omewhat like thoe of the Back; the tranvere Procees, and pinous ones, are omewhat rough, for the better inertion of many Mucles, which are fatned there.
All the Vertebrae of the Neck,Foramina Vertebrarum Colli have two mall Foramina each, which lye in the Head of the tranvere Procees, erving for the paage of the Vertebral Arteries.
Their oblique Procees have this obervable in them, their uperior ones are omewhat hollowih, to receive the inferior Convex ones, that the motion of the Neck be freer.

The Back has twelve Vertebrae; Back 12. yet I once aw a Skeleton that had thirteen, and thirteen Ribs; they are bigger than thoe of the Neck, but les then thoe of the Loins; their Spinal Procees are not fork'd but pointed, and lye one over another; the tranvere are hort, but large, and blunt, and have a Cavity to receive the Heads of the Ribs; the oblique are harp, and mooth, and o conequently little motion,Vertebrae Cotales. thee are call'd
the Cotal Vertebrae; the eleventh Vertebra has its pinal Proces, not lying over the other, as thoe above it.
The lat Vertebra of the Back has this to be oberved in it; it receives none, but is received, both by the eleventh of the Back, and firt of the Loins; on this depends the greatet motion of the Back.

The five of the Loins are larger than thoe of the Back,Loins 5. and their Articulation looer, their tranvere Procees are more long and fine than thoe of the Back, which erve as Ribs, as it were, yet the firt and fifth are horter than the ret; their Foramina Nervina are excavated only out of the lower Vertebra, N. B. whereas thoe of the Back equally out of both, but thoe of the Neck only out of the uperior; their poterior Spines, are hort, blunt and thick, a little broad, and turn a little upwards, that the bending of the Body be no way hindred; and whereas in the other Vertebrae, the upper oblique Procees receive the lower, in thee the lower receive the upper.
The firt of thee Vertebrae is call'd Renalis, Renalis. the Kidneys being lodged at the ide of it; the other four have no particular Name.

The Os Sacrum, Os Sacrum. or holy Bone, o call'd, as ome think, becaue the Antients ued to ave this part as Sacred in Sacrifices; but I think rather from
< in non-Latin alphabet > , as the Greeks call it, which ignifies Magnum, as well as Sacrum, it being the bigget Bone of all the Spine. It's immoveable, and erves as a Bais or Pedetal to the whole Spine; it's of a omewhat triangular Figure, with the point downwards; it's Concavous within, which helps to form the Pelvis, alo mooth; behind it's Convex, and unequal, many Mucles ariing, and being inerted here, it eems as if it were compoed of five or ix Bones, (as indeed it is in Infants) its Oification beginning at o many points, but its edges, or rather, if you will, its tranvere Procees look but like one continued Bone, as it is; the Foramen Spinale towards its lower part is very mall; its Foramina Nervina are before and
behind, and not on the ides, as in the other Vertebrae; its pinal Procees are very mall, the lat being only a mall round Protuberance, it oblique Procees are hardly viible, except the uperior ones; the parts which compoe the Os Sacrum, are plac'd in the number of the Vertebrae, not by reaon of their ue, but becaue of their reemblance, for otherwie they are immoveable: The Os Sacrum may be aid to be divided into five Vertebrae of different bignes, whereof the uperior is bigget, they diminihing as they decend, the lat being the leat; thee eperate eaily in Infants, by reaon the Cartilages which unite them, are not fully oified; but in Adults, they all make up but one intire Bone.

This Bone eems to have everal Ues,Ves. the firt is, as I have already remark'd, to erve as a Foundation to the whole Spine. Secondly, to help to contain the parts of the Hypogatrium, by forming Cavity, as I have aid. The third to defend them; the fourth to Articulate the Bones of the
Hips; the fifth to give Origin and Inertion to many Mucles.

To the end of this Bone are annex'd two or three little Bones call'd Oa Coccygis, Oa Coccygis. the Cuckow's Beak; ome call them the Rump-bones: They have a omewhat looe Articulation, and tyed by Cartilages one to another, the lat is the mallet: They have this looe Articulation, that they may give way to the Foetus in the Birth, therefore in Women thee Bones are always more bent backwards than in Men; they end in a Cartilaginous point, to which is tyed the Intetinum Rectum; they have no thing more material in them, having neither Proces nor Cavity.
We hall now proceed to the Bones of the Breat and Ribs,Bones of the Breat. which is the econd Diviion of the Trunk.

The Ribs are twenty-four in number,Ribs 24. twelve on each ide; to be well-intructed in all which concerns the Ribs, we mut oberve everal things, as their Subtance, Figure, Connexions, Parts, Diviion and Ue, of all which in order.

The ubtance of the Ribs is partly Bony,Subtance of the Ribs. and partly Cartilaginous, that end next the Vertebra, being of a harder and more olid and thick ubtance than that towards the Sternon, which is flattih, o les capable of being broke; or that end towards the Sternon being more pongy in ubtance, all the Ribs end towards the Breat by Cartilages, increaing in length as the Ribs decend; and thoe Cartilages of the uperior Ribs, are harder than thoe of the inferior; ometimes thee Cartilages grow bony in Old People, o that they cannot be eparated by a Knife.

The Ribs have a ort of Semicircular Figure,Figure. making a ort of Arch; when two are together, they make a kind of a true Circle, Concave inwardly, to form the Capacity of the Thorax, and to contain the Lungs and Heart, and Convex outwardly, to reit outward force; the farther they depart from the Sternon, the more round they are in their own Body; they are not equally big, for the uperior are horter, the middle bigget of
all, and the inferior one leat of all; their upper ides are thick, blunt, and broad; one edge is call'd the interior, the other the exterior Lip; their under edges are harp, having in their inide a long Sinus, or Furrow, in which lye the Intercotal Veels.

The Ribs are Articulated by their Extremities,Articulation. both to the Vertebrae of the Thorax, and Sternon; that Articulation with the Back is moveable, the other not; the long Head of each Rib is Articulated by a ingle Arthrodia; it has a mall Protuberance cloathed with a Cartilage, which head is received into a Sinus of the tranvere Proces of the Vertebra; 'tis this Proces which upports the Ribs, and hinders them from coming lower in Expiration: You mut oberve,N. B. that the back-part of every Rib is higher than the fore-part, till the Cartilage be join'd, which turning a little up, makes the two ends of an equal height, o that by the riing of the Ribs, the Breat is enlarged. We mut alo take notice, that almot all the Ribs have a Communication with the
Sternon, either directly or indirectly; that is, the uperior ones are by a direct inertion, but the lower by an indirect, which is by Cartilages adhering to the uperior.

All the Ribs make a ort of Angle by their Cartilages towards the Sternon, which erves to increae the Spring of the Cartilages, that the Ribs be brought down again, having been rais'd in Inpiration. It ometimes happens, though eldom, that thee Cartilages are oified, which occaions an Incurable Athma; the lat, or lowet Rib in Man, have no Cartilage as the ret; the lower the Ribs, are, longet and more movable,N. B. becaue Repiration in Man is downwards, but in Birds upwards.

The Ribs are commonly divided in two orts,Ribs of two orts. as true or fale, but I think they may well be all accounted true, except the lat, (being join'd mediateor immediately to the Sternon by Cartilages) which has none, o only may be term'd a fale Rib; however it being a common received Opinion, I
hall make the diviion: the long or true are even on each ide,True 14. and are the uperior ones; the firt of which has no motion at all, it being as a prop for all the ret, but as they decend they increae in motion; they are Articulated to the Vertebrae of the Back by a ort of double Arthrodia, which makes a Ginglimus, and to the Sternon by Synarthrois, the three lowet of which are by ome call'd the Pectoral Ribs.Cotae Pectorales.

The fale or batard are five on each ide,Fale, 10. the four uppermot of which have at their Extremities towards the Sternon long Cartilages, bending upwards, and cleaving only one to another; that is, the lowet to the uperior, o not directly united to the Sternon, as the firt even are; which was the Reaon the Antients gave them the Name of Spurious: The lat has no Cartilage at its end, the edge of the Diaphragme being tyed to it.

All the Ribs, as I have already demontrated, are received both into the tranvere Procees, and body of the Vertebrae; except the two or three
lat, which are only received into the body of the Vertebrae.

The Ribs are to defend the Heart and Lungs,Ve. &c. from all orts of external Injuries, o that they be not pret, but have free motion, which were it not bony, would be always in danger of being offended; they alo erve to utain the Repiratory Mucles.

The Cartilages of the Ribs have this Ue,Ve of the Cartilages. that is, when the Ribs are drawn omething upwards in Inpiration, they draw them down again with a ort of Spring; for all Cartilaginous Bodies are indued with a ort of Elaticity, o that they always recover their firt Figure.
