This Mechanim is oberved in various Animals, for in Birds the Sternon is immovable, becaue the flying Mucles arie from thence; o that if the Sternon had any thing to do in Repiration, it would be hinder'd; therefore Nature has contrived another Artifice, which is this, between every Rib there's a little Bone, plac'd omewhat obliquely, o that if one
moves, the other follow by conent.

All thee Birds have no Diaphragm, but intead thereof two Bladders, which reach to the bottom of their Bellies, they erve for the Diaphragma, and alo help to keep them upended in the Air: Thoe Creatures which have a Diaphragma, breathe downwards, but Birds, &c. which have none, breathe upwards.
In Amphibious Creatures, as the Tortoie, &c. their shell is in place of Ribs, and Frogs have only one Rib on a ide, to defend the Lungs.

The Breat-bone is call'd Sternon, Sternon made up of three Bones. or Os Pectoris, ituated in the middle of the Anterior part of the Breat, compoed of two or three Bones, having the Productions of the Cartilages of the Ribs inerted into their ides, of a reddih fungous Subtance.

To conider it well, it mut be examined at two different times; for in Infants it's almot all Cartilaginous, except the firt Bone where the Claviculae are fatned. In Old People I have een it all oified, except the firt
with the econd at its juncture, but in thoe of Middle Age, partly Bony, and partly Cartilaginous, the uperior Bone always oifies firt, and the inferior lat. In the Sternon of Infants you may perceive even or eight Junctures, as if o many Bones, but in the eventh or eighth Year, they uniting, make up but three or four at mot.

The firt or uperior Bone of the Sternon, Firt Bone. is more thick and olid than the ret, made in the hape of a Crecent almot, at each ide of its uperior part, it has a Sinus to receive the head of the Clavicula; at its top it has a Lunated Sinus call'd Jugulum; Jugulum. it has alo a mall long Sinus on its inide, to give way to the Apera Arteria: It's immovable.
The econd Bone is narrower,Second Bone. longer and thinner, having at its ides many Sinoities, to receive the Cartilages of the Ribs.

The third Bone is les than the econd,Third Bone. but broader, at the lower end of which is annex'd a Cartilage call'd Xiphoides, vel Mucroconita, vel Eniformis,
the Sword-like Cartilage;Cartilago Eniformis. it's of a Triangular Figure, it erves to defend the uperior Orifice of the Stomach: It's this place which is call'd Scrobiculus Cordis, the Heart-pit; the Diaphragma is alo fatned to it; a trong Ligament of the Liver, call'd Supenorium, is tyed to it, for in Inpiration the Ribs being draw upwards, then the Liver by its weight keeps this from moving, and when in Expiration the Ribs aume their former Figure, this by its Cartilaginous Spring aumes his alo.

The Ues of the Sternon are,Ves of the Sternon. firt, to unite the Ribs, that their motion may be all at one and the ame time, alo to receive the Clavicula: Latly, to faten the Mediatinum, which is a Membrane that divides the Breat in two.

The third part that compoe the Trunk,Oa Innominata. are call'd Oa Innominata, becaue of a very trange Figure; they are in number two, one on each side of the Os Sacrum, having where they are united to it, many Depreions and Riings, for their greater Strength and
Connexion,Articulation. being Articulated before by Synchondrois, o make up that Cavity call'd the Pelvis, Pelvis. which contains the (Womb in Women) Bladder, and Intetinum Rectum, with other of the Guts.

In Children each Bone conits of three,Each conits of three in Children. all of them meeting in that deep Cavity, call'd Acetabulum, which receives the head of the Fenier, but as we grow in Years they all make but one Bone, yet then, for better ditinction, nam'd as three, as the Os Ileum, Ichium, and Pubis, of all which in order.

The Ileum is the uperior part of the Bone,Os lleum. o call'd, becaue mot part of the Ileum-Gut lyes on its Internal Face; from it's External arie the Muculi Glutei: It's the bigget of the three, and join'd with the Os Sacrum.

Things to be conider'd in this Bone,Spina Ilei. are, firt, its Figure, which is Semicircular. Secondly, its top, which is call'd the Ridg, Comb, or Spine, being covered with a Cartilage: Its Internal
Face is Concave, and its Exterior Convex: It has three Protuberances, being rather o many parts of the Spine;Three parts of the Spine. one forwards, call'd Spina Anterior Superior; another below, call'd Spina Anterior Inferior, les than the former; and a third behind, call'd Spina Poterior.

The Os Ichium, Os Ichium or Coxendicis, is the lower part of the Os Innominatum, in which is to be conider'd two parts; firt, It's Superior, which makes up the greatet part of the Cotula, or Acetabulum. Secondly, Its Inferior, or lower part, which we it on, which is call'd Tuberoitas Ichii; Tuberoitas. it has a Sinuoity on its inner ide, where the Muculus Obturator Internus winds about; the Mucles of the Penis, and Elevators of the Anus, have their Origin from the Tuberoity of the Ichium.

The Os Pubis, Os Pubis. or Pectinis, by us the Share-bone, is the fore-part of the Os Innominatum; it's join'd forwardly to its Fellow by Synchondrois, the hinder part of it forms part of the Acetabulum;
the uperior part is call'd the Spine, to which the Mucles of the Abdomen are fatned; where this joins with the Ichium there's large Foramen, call'd Ovale, Foramen Ovale Ois Pubis. cover'd with very a trong Ligamentous Membrane; above this Foramen there's Sinus, by which the Crural Veels pas to the Thigh.

All thee Bones being join'd together in their middle, make up that deep Cavity call'd Acetabulum, vel Cotula, in which the head of the Os Femoris enters, which is tipt with a Cartilage, call'd Supercilium.
Thee Bones are more ample and large in Women than Men, Oa Pubis, larget in Women. and thoe which have them mot advanc'd, have the eaiet Labour.

The Antients believed, that in Labour the Oa Pubis eparated for the more eaie Delivery of the Birth,The Oa Pubis do not eparate in Labour. nay, Bartholinus is of this Opinion, for he ays, that in a Woman newly Deliver'd, you may divide them with the back of a Knife; but I preume it's not o, for they eparate not the leat; 'tis only the Os Coccygis which gives
way a little by bending backwards, for mot pain is felt when the Foetus paes by the Fundament; yet ome have a more looe Articulation of their Bones, and o perhaps might bring them into this Error.

div.head: Demontration IV.
Of the Bones of the Superior Extremities.
div.p: I Have Demontrated all the Bones which make up the two parts of the Skeleton, there remains now only the third part, which is thoe of the Extremities.
The Extremities,Extremities, Vpper and Lower. or rather the Limbs, are either Superior, as the Arms; or Inferior, as the Legs.

Although there be no part which does not furnih us with ome Subject of Admiration, yet we mut all agree, that the Arm hath as great a hare, if not more, than any other; for which reaon Aritotle call'd it the Organ of
Organs, and the Intrument of Intruments; and ince Nature has given to all Animals, omething particular, either to defend themelves againt others, and preerve themelves from external Injuries; or ele to offend; we may ay then, that Man has received two things preferable to Animals, to wit, Reaon and Hands, the one for Counel and Conduct, the other for Execution of our Will; 'tis thee Hands which gives him the Soveraign Command over all Creatures be he never o Cruel, Strong, or Swift; for of what Advantage would all our Reaon and Conduct be, if we had not Hands to perform what Reaon dictates: I could ay much more on this Subject, but that I am here on plain Demontration, and not Philoophizing.
The Arm,Diviion. Arm, five parts. generally o called, has five parts, as the Clavicula, Scapula, Shoulder, Arm, and Hand, of all which in due coure.

1. The Clavicula, Clavicula which ome place among the Bones of the Spine, but I
think it rather belongs to thoe of the Arms, as I hall hew in its ue, the whole motion of the Arm depending on this Bone; It's call'd Clavicula, I uppoe, being a diminutive from Clavis a Key, becaue the Keys in old time were like an Figure. in Padua they have uch ort of Keys till, as I am inform'd by thoe who have been there; it's not o crooked in Women as in Men;Articulation. it's Articulated by one end to the Acromium of the Scapula, and by the other to the upper part of the firt Bone of the Sternon; by a ort of Arthrodia, yet has but little motion; the more crooked thee Bones are, the more force and agility has the Arm.Subtance. It's hollow in the middle, and contains Marrow, as all long Bones, but towards the ends Spongy; that end towards the Acromium is not very thick, but rough, and unequal, the end towards the Sternon moother: It's alo here outwardly Convex, but inwardly Concave, to give way to the Veels which pas under it, otherwie it would have pret them; but towards the Acromium, Convex inwardly,
and Concave outwardly, for the more convenient ituation of the Deltoid Mucle, which would otherwie appear too bulky, and make the Breat look deform'd.

They erve to uphold the Scapula and Humerus from falling on the Breat,Ve. which they do when this Bone happens to be Fractured; the whole motion of the Arm depends alo on this Bone; for Brutes having no Claviculae, cannot move their Fore-legs o readily as Man, or as ome Animals which have them, as Monkeys, Squirrels, &c.

2. The Scapula, Scapula. or Shoulder bone, is ituated on the back-part of the Thorax, being only fatned with Mucles, (o more looe, that the motion be freer and eaie) except in its Acromium where it's Articulated with the Clavicula; it's of a Triangular Figure,Figure. whereof two Angles are Poterior, and one Anterior, Its inward Face is Concave, as well to accommodate it elf to the Ribs whereon it lyes, as to contain a Mucle, but outward Gibbous, thicker on its edges than in the
middle, being there tranparent, and very thin; o that in a Caries of that part we cannot expect Exfoliation, no Medullar Glands being there, it's nourihed from its ides.

Parts to be conider'd in this Bone,Procees, three. are firt, its Procees, which are three, firt is a thin, but riing Proces, in the middle of its outide, extending all its length, it's call'd the Spine;Spine Acromium its Point or Extremity is call'd the Acromium, in which is a flattih Sinus to receive the Clavicula: Some ay that this Proces is a ditinct Bone from the Scapula, becaue in Infants its only Cartilaginous, which oifying by degrees, makes up but one Bone; the econd is les, and plac'd at the uperior part of the Neck, which advances above the Head of the Bone of the Arm: It's curved, and call'd Coracoides, Coracoides Ancyroides the Crows-bill, or Ancyroides, ome call it only Proceus Curvatus, it trengthens the Articulation of the Humerus. The third, or middle one, is call'd Cervix, Cervix. is which in a omewhat flat Sinus to receive the head of the Humerus, call'd Glenoides; the Humerus is
tyed to it by a trong, but omewhat looe Ligament; the edges of this Sinus is tipt with a Cartilaginous Ligament, which hinders the Humerus from being too eaily Dilocated; there's alo a trong Ligament from the Acromium to the Proceus Coracoides, which, together with the Acromium,
hinders the Humerus from being too eaily Dilocated upwards, except this Ligament or the Acromiune be broken.
The edges of this Bone are call'd Cota. Cota.
It has three Angles,Angles, three. 1. The Inferior. 2. Poterior. 3. Cervix; that part which reaches from the Poterior to the Inferior Angle, is call'd the Bais of the Scapula. Bais.

It has two notable Sinues Sinues. one on each ide the Spine, where the Muculi Infra, and Supra Spinati lye; the lower Sinus is larget; in its inide Concave part lyes the Muculus Subcapularis, vel Immerus.

The Scapula has many Ues;Ve. firt, it gives Origin to many Mucles, it fatens alo the Arm to the Body, and
erves to upport it, to the end it may have all its motions.

The third part of the uperior Limb is the Os Humeri, Humerus. or Shoulderbone, it's the tronget and larget of all that compoe the Arm; it's long and round in its fore part, but omewhat flat behind; its uperior part is Articulated to the Cervix of the Scapula by Arthrodia; Articulation. at its lower end with the Cubitus by Ginglimus; it alo touches the Radius by Arthrodia.
To examine the parts of the Humerus, you mut conider its Extremities,Parts to be conider'd. and Body.

The Body is long and round, within it contains a Marrow;Body. its Figure is not abolutely treight, but omewhat hollow inwardly, and bunching outwardly, to fortifie it in its Actions; there is oberved a Line which decends and terminates in two Procees, which erve to faten the Mucles inerted here.

The uperior Extremity of the Humerus is bigger and more pongy than the Inferior;Superior Extremity. and contains a Medullar Juice; it's call'd the Head, cover'd
with a Cartilage: It's encompaed on all ides with Ligaments and Membranes, which proceed from the Glenoid Cavity of the Scapula; a little below this Head,Procees. there's a round part a little maller, call'd the Neck; there's at the hinder part of this end two rough unequal Procees, into which everal Tendons and Ligaments are inerted; o that great Care ought to be had in Wounds, or Ulcers of this part, let you mitake the Roughnes for a Carioity;N. B. between thee inequalities there's a long Slit, or Sciure, in which the Tendon of the Muculus Biceps paes.

The Inferior Extremity of the Humerus is les, flatter, and harder than the other; it has three Procees, two whereof are call'd Condyli, Condyli the Exterior and Interior: The Bone eems here to be divided in two parts. The third, or middle Proces, is large, and call'd Trochlea, Trochlea. the Pully; it has two large Sinues, which receive the Procees of the Vlna, to which it's Articulated by Ginglimus; the back Sinus is large and deep, which receives the
Olecranon, but that on its fore part maller.

The fourth part, Brachium, two Bones. or that which is trictly call'd the Arm, is compoed of two Bones, the bigget and longet call'd Vlna, the leer Radius; for had this part been made up only of one Bone join'd by Ginglimus, we could do nothing ele but extend and draw up the Arm, and not turn it upwards and downwards, which is perform'd by means of the Radius, for which end it's Articulated by Arthrodia.

The two Bones are not both of a bignes, for which ome ditinguih them by the Names of Major and Minor Focile; in their middle they are omewhat ditant the one from the other, for the more Commodious Situation of the Mucles, Paage of the Veels, and principally for the Eae of Motion.

1. The Vlna, or Cubitus, Ulna. o call'd, by reaon it's this Bone which makes the Elbow; it's bigget at the uperior part, and had two large Procees, that in the back-part is call'd Olecranon
Olecranon.
vel Ancon, which when the Arm is extended, is received into the large Poterior Sinus of the Trochlea, o tops the Arm from going further backwards, it's otherwie call'd the Elbow; the other is les, and received into the fore Sinus of the Trochlea, it tops the Arm from being bent too cloe forward; below this is another very mall Proces, into which the Tendon of the Muculus Biceps is inerted.

It has two mall Sinues,Sinues. the Latteral one receiving the Head of the Radius, the other is between the two large Procees, and receives the Trochlea of the Humerus; it may be call'd Sigmatoides, becaue it reembles the Greek Letter Sigma.

At the body,Three Angles in its Body. of middle of this Bone, there's oberved three Angles, whereof the Inferior is call'd the Spine, and is very treight; the other two are oblique, the one of which is the Anterior Angle, the other Poterior; one ide is very mooth and equal, the other pretty rough, ome Tendons being inerted there.

The Inferior part of this Bone has two Eminencies, and one Cavity; the firt of the Eminencies is eated at the lateral part, and is received by the Glenoid Cavity of the Radius: The econd is at the very Extremity, and may be call'd Styloides, Stylodes. it erves to trengthen the Articulation; the Cavity or Sinuoity is at the end of the Bone, and helps to make the Arthrodia with the Carpus: This Bone at its uperior end receives the Radius, but is received by the Radius at its lower end.

The Radius Radius. is the econd Bone of the Arm, (or as ome call it, the Fore-Arm) o call'd, becaue it reembles the Spoke of a Wheel;Articulation. it's Articulated in its uperior part, two manner of ways: Firt, with the External Condyl of the Humerus. Secondly, with the Ulna, and both by Arlhrodia: It's likewie Articulated two manner of ways in its Inferior part, either with the Bones of the Carpus at its Extremity, or with the Vlna, on its latter part: The Radius is mallet in its Superior, but larget in its Inferior part.

The Things to be oberved in its Superior part are thee;Superior part. Firt, its Head, which is round and polihed, at the end of which is a Glenoid Cavity, which as I have already remark'd, receives the External Condyl of the Humerus; the Neck is omewhat long. Now this is very obervable, that the Ligament which comes from the other Bone to join it, is not inerted in it as in other Bones, but only encompaes this Neck as a Ring, o that it may turn,Ligamentum Admirabile. for its Prone, and Supine Motions, which had the Ligament been inerted into it, it could not have done, yet at the ame time it's trong enough to keep it firm; the whole motion of the Writ is perform'd by the Radius; the Tuberoity or Eminence is eated jut below the Neck, and is received into the lateral Superior Sinus of the Ulna.

In its middle it has an obtue Angle, which ome call the Spine, which gradually grows bigger as it inclines towards the Carpus, different from the Cubitus, Body. which diminihes: It's in this that we may admire Nature, which
not being able to avoid making thee two Bones unequal in their Extremities, has found means to make the Arm equally trong in all parts, by placing the weaket part of one Bone againt the tronget of the other.

At its Inferior part many Sinuoities appear,Inferior part. which are as mall Gutters, that o the Tendons be not incommoded; it has alo a Cavity at its Extremity, which receives one of the Bones of the Carpus; at its lower end it has a blunt Proces,Matoides. call'd Matoides: from the Internal Angle of this Bone, there's a long broad Ligamentous Membrane, which unites it to the Internal Angle of the Ulna, according to its length.
The Ulna erves only for Flexion and Extenion,Ve of the Radius and Ulna. and the Radius for Pronation and Supination.
The fifth and lat part of the Arm,5. Hand. generally o call'd, is the Hand, which is ubdivided into the Carpus, Metacarpus. and Fingers.

The Carpus,
Carpus, eight Bones. or Writ, is compoed of eight mall Bones plac'd in two ranks, four in a rank, three of the
firt rank are united very cloe on their ides, the two greatet of which are received into the Cavity of the Radius by Arthrodia, for the motion of the Hand in their Inferior part, they touch the three Bones of the econd rank of the Carpus; the third of the firt rank which is next in bignes, and received in the Cavity at the lower Extremity of the Ulna; the fourth of the firt rank which lyes on the outide, a little out of its rank, is the leat of the four: The four Bones of the econd rank are join'd together on their ides by Harmonia, as the Bones of the firt rank are, alo one to another o; but at their ends, to the Bones of the Metacarpus by Enarthrois, having an obcure motion: The firt Bone of this rank is eated more within the Hand, that the Thumb be better utain'd; the econd and third utain the firt and econd Bone of the Metacarpus; the fourth Bone of this econd rank utains the third and fourth Bones of the Metacarp, by its two Glenoid Cavities: All thee Bones are Convex on the back-part, but hollowih
within, for the more afe paage of the Veels, and Tendons of the Muculi Flexores, being likewie guarded by the Ligamentum Anulare which covers them,Ligamentum Anulare. and joins together all thee Bones.

The Metacarpus is compoed of four long hollowih Bones, Metacarpus, four Bones. containing Marrow in their Internal Sinues; there are ome who make five Bones of the Metacarp, and for that end add thereto the firt Bone of the Thumb, but it ought not to be numerated among thoe of the Metacarp, it having a manifet, but the others a very obcure Motion.

Thee four Bones are united by their Superior Extremities with the Carpus, Articulation. as I have already mentioned, by means of trong Cartilaginous Ligaments, and with the firt Bones of the Fingers by Arthrodia; they alo touch one another in their lateral Parts, epecially towards the Carpus; about the middle they are a little eparated to give way to the Muculi Interoei: They are Convex, and mooth outwardly,
but Concave inwardly; all their Extremities are tipt with Cartilages.
Thee four Bones are not of an equal bignes, for that which utains the Index is the larget, that which utains the middle Finger les, and o on to the very lat, which is leat of all.

The Fingers,Fingers. counting the Thumb, are five, having three Bones each; thee Orders may be well call'd Phalangi Digitorum, Phalangi Digitorum. the firt larget, the econd les, the third leat of all; their outward Face round, but plain, and even within, Articulated to each other by Ginglimus, except the firt rank, which are join'd by Arthrodia to the Metacarp, and o have all orts of Motion, but the other Joints have only Flexion and Extenion: The leat Bones are not hollow as the ret, but pongy.

The Greeks call the Hand in general Cheir, but the Thumb Antichier, as much as to ay, an oppoite Hand: The econd Finger, counting the Thumb as one, is call'd Indicator, becaue we are apt to point it, when we intend to
hew omething: The third is call'd the Middle-Finger, becaue of its ituation, and is the longet of all: The fourth is call'd the Annular, by reaon Rings are ued the mot upon this Finger: The fifth and leat is call'd the Auricular, being mot fit to pick the Ear with.
I will not peak here of the Oa Seamoidea, which are ometimes found in the Joints of the Fingers, till we explain the Bones of the Toes.

div.head: Demontration. V.
Of the Bones of the Inferior Extremities.
div.p: WE come now to Demontrate the Bones of the Inferior Limbs, which is the lat part of the Oteology.
The Leg,Diviion. generally o taken, may be divided into the Bones of the Thigh, Leg, and Foot.

We hall begin with the Thighbone,Os Femoris. which is but one in each Leg: It's the longet larget, and tronget Bone of the Body, being form'd to utain the weight of the whole Body; ome aying that the word Femur is derived from the Verb Fero, to carry or bear; it's imbow'd a little on the fore-part, but hollow in its back.
We mut examine in this Bone everal Things.Things to be examined in it.

Firt, At its upper end it has a great round head, cover'd with a mooth Cartilage,Articulation. and received into the Acetabulum by Enarthrois, and tyed therein by a hort, but trong round Ligament, which is fatned in the very middle of the Head;Caput. under this Head lyes the Neck,Cervix. which is long, and lyes obliquely, otherwie the Head coud never have entred conveniently into the Acetabulum, conidering its poture in the Skeleton; and alo the Neck carrying it elf outwardly, puts thee Bones the one from the other, and o caues that the Body be carried more conveniently and urely.

At this Extremity or End lyes two Apophyes, Trochanters. behind the Neck, call'd Trochanters, which are derived from the Greek work < in non-Latin alphabet > , which ignifies to turn, becaue many of the Mucles of the Thigh, epecially the Rotatores, are fatned to thee Protuberances, the Anterior and Upper one is the bigget, the Poterior and Lower the les: the outward part of this Bone is mooth, but rough within, many Mucles ariing from thence: This
Bone has a large long Cavity all its length, full of Marrow; it's of a crooked Figure, o that Surgeons in Fractures of this Bone, ought well to conider its ound Figure: Towards its lower end it grows thicker and larger, ending in two large heads, which are received into the two hallow Sinus's of the Tibia; between thee two Procees is a Sinus which receives a riing Proces of the Tibia, o that here the Thigh-bone is Articulated by a looe Ginglimus; the fore-part of this Articulation is call'd the Knee, the Poterior the Ham.
The Leg,Leg. trictly o call'd, is compoed of two Bones, the greater and internal call'd Tibia, the leer and external Fibula, by many alo Focile majus & minus.

The Tibia is the bigget,Tibia. hollow within, and full of Marrow, it's partly Triangular; its harp Angle of Spine makes that we call the Shin; it has a ridge like a Proces at its upper end, which is received by the Sinus at the extremity of the Femur; on each ide of this Proces, there's two longih,
hallow Cavities, to receive the two lower Eminences of the Femur: Thee hallow Cavities are deepned by a lunated Cartilage, which is thick about the edges, but grows thin towards the Centre; as this Bone approaches towards the Tarus it leens, but grows more olid; at the lower part of the Tibia there's notable Proces which makes the Internal Ancle,Malleolus Internus. which hinders the luxation of the Foot, in keeping in firm: At the bottom of the Tibia there's a Sinus, which receives the Convex head of the Atragalus; this Bone upports the whole Body.

The Fibula, Fibula. or Perone, is as long as the other, but much lenderer, plac'd on the outide of the Leg; its uperior head reaches not quite to the Os Femoris, but has a hallow Sinus on its ide, which receives a mall lateral Proces of the Tibia; this Articulation is fortified with a Ligament; its Body is of a Triangular Figure as well as the Tibia, but a little more irregular; the lower end is received by the Tibia, and extending it elf to the ide of the
Atragalus, Malleolus Externus. makes the external Ankle; both thee Ankles, or rather Procees, hinder the Talus from being too eaily dilocated.
Thee two Bones eparate a little one from another in their middle, to make room for the Mucles and Veels.

Upon the Knee lyes a mall round Bone,Rotula. gibbous, and plain without, but hollowih within, about two Inches broad, omewhat like the Bos of a Buckler, the middle being thick, and thinning towards its edges, call'd Rotula, Patella, the Knee-pan; it's movable, and Articulated by a ort of Ginglimus, cover'd with the Aponeurois of four Mucles, being the Extenders of the Leg; internally it has a very mooth Cartilage, to facilitate its motions.

Some believe it's to trengthen the Articulation of the Joint,Ve. but it's no uch thing, it being rather plac'd to caue greater force in extending the Leg, by reaon the Tendons of the Muculi Extenores pas over it; for if the Tendons had not this hillock, as
it were, to pas over, but lain flat on the Bones, they could not have had o much force, as by this means to extend the Leg.
It's of a hard Subtance,Subtance. but omewhat pongy within, and tyed looly by Ligaments.
The Foot is ubdivided into the Tarus, Metatarus, Oa Pedis. and Toes.
The Tarus is made up of even Bones,Tarus. differing much in hape and bignes; four of which have particular Names, the other three no other but Oa Cuneiformia in general.

Firt, The Talus, vel Atragalus, Talus. is of a very trange figure, in which is to be conider'd its ix Faces: Firt, the Superior, which is very mooth and convex, Articulated with the Tibia, hedged in by both Malleoli: Secondly, its Anterior, which is a great head which enters the Cavity of the Os Naviculare, with which it's trongly Articulated: Thirdly, the Poterior, which has a Protuberance received by the Os Calcis: Fourthly, the Inferior, which is rough and unequal,
riing in ome places, and inking in others: The fifth and ixth are the two Lateral Faces, hedged in, as I aid, by the Malleoli; it erves as a Bais to utain the Tibia, which upports the whole Body.

The econd Bone is the Os Calcis, Os Calcis. or Heel bone, the bigget and larget of the even, but mot porous of all; it's this Bone which hinders the Body from falling backwards, being eated at the Poterior part of the Foot; it lyes uner the Talus, to which it's Articulated; it's alo join'd with a flat head to the Os Cuboides; behind it has a long Proces, to which is tyed the great Tendon, call'd Nervus Hectoricus, vel Achillis; it has a large Sinus on its inide, by which the Tendons pas under the Foot, it's very unequal on its outide, for the inertion of Ligaments and Tendons.

The third is call'd Os Scaphoides, Cymbiforme, vel Naviculare, Os Naviculare. the Boat-like Bone, behind it has a large Cavity, wherein the head of the Atrgalus is received: but before it has three Eminences, which unites it to the Oa Cuneiformia.

The fourth has a omewhat unequal Figure of ix irregular ides,Os Cuboides. therefore call'd Cuboides, the Die-like Bone, by ome Multiforme; in its fore-part it's join'd to the fourth and fifth Bone of the Metatare, behind to the Os Calcis, its inide to the Oa Cuneiformia; it lyes on the outide of the Foot, and utains the little Toes.

The other three are call'd Oa Cuneiformia, Oa Cuneiformia. or Wedge-like Bones, and lye all in a rank, but differ in bignes one from another, join'd behind to the Os Naviculare, and before to the three firt Bones of the Metatarus: Thee Bones are Convex outwardly, but hollowih within, for the more afe paage of the Veels; there's a broad Ligament which paes from the Os Calcis to the Bones of the Metatarus, Ligamentum Latum. under which the Veels and Mucles lye; for if there were no uch, in long tanding on the Foot, the action of the Mucles, and circulation of the Juices would have been hindred: It's a ort of Ligamentum Annulare.

The Metatarus, Metatarus. or Intep, is compoed of five long Bones, placed at the
ide of each other, to utain each a Toe, very cloe where they are united to the Tarus, but part a little in their middle, to give place to the Muculi Interoei; convex outwardly, but hollow within, for the better lying of the Mucles, and paage of the Veels; their lower ends are round, and received into the Cavities of the firt Phalanx of the Bones of the Toes by Arthrodia; that which utains the great Toe the bigget, the next les, and o on to the leat of all.
The Bones of the Toes are in number 14,Digiti Pedis. for all have three Bones each, except the great Toe, which has only two; their Articulation the ame as in the Fingers and the ame Obervations.

There are ometimes, found in the Articulations of the Fingers,Oa Seamoidea. but epecially in the Toes, ome very mall Bones, call'd Oa Seamoidea, Seed-like Bones, becaue they reemble much the Semina Seami; they are fatned only by Ligaments in number uncertain, ometimes more, ometimes les, in ome none at all.
They have the ame Ue as the Patella. Ve.

The Bones of the Foot being all united together, may well be compar'd to a Lever plac'd under any great weight, which we intend to raie; for the convex part of the Talus being plac'd jut under the Tibia, which, as I have hew'd, utains the whole Body; the long hinder Proces of the Os Calcis, being, as it were, the handle of this Lever, and o rais'd, (as by the Hands) by the Nervus Hectoricus, which is trongly inerted there: This Nerve, or rather Tendon, is compoed of three or four Tendons of everal Mucles of the Leg, as Solaris, Gatrochnemii, &c. and with it the whole Body is rais'd, as may be een when we rear our elves on our Toes.

There's one thing very Curious to oberve,N. B. in the bending of the Joints of the Skeleton; for all the Junctures of the Arms, as Elbow, Writ, and Fingers, bend upwards, but otherwie in the Legs; for at the Thigh it bends forwards, that we may it when weary; at the Ham backwards, at the Ankle forwards again, and the Toes backwards: All thee everal bendings give us a greater trength, both to walk, and rie when down, which we could not do, if the bendings were otherwie dipoed.

div.head: AN APPENDIX TO THE Doctrine of the Bones; SHEWING,

The Bet Method of Whitening, Cleaning, and Preparing the Bones of Man's Body, for making a Movable Skeleton, wherein the Bones may have the ame Motions, as in a Living Subject; together with the manner of Uniting them together.
div.p: WHen you have a Body, that you intend to ave the Bones, towards forming a skeleton, proceed in this manner

Firt,No Bone to be lot. Take Care that in Decarning the Bones, you loe none, although never o mall, for by o doing you will poil the Beauty of your Skeleton; alo be Cautious let you cut away any of the Subtance of the Bones with your knife, which if you are not aware you may do, epecially when you come towards the more Spongy, and Cartilaginous Extremities of them; as in the Bones of the Breat, Cartilaginous parts of the Ribs, and Cartilago Eniformis, alo the Proceus Styloides of the Bais of the Cranium, is very apt to be eparated, unles you are careful, epecially in young Subjects; but if by chance you loe any of the mall Bones, get one in its place from any other Skeleton, and about the ame bignes; alo if you happen to break any Bone, join it again with Lithecolla, the ame as Maons ue to join their broken Stones together; or a Preparation of Wax and Roin.

That you be at the les trouble in preparing your Skeleton for boiling,Method to be oberved in boiling and eparating the parts. you ought to divide it in everal parts, before you put it into your Chaldron to boil, which you mut perform thus; firt, Artificially bare from the Mucles, the firt and econd Vertebra of the Neck, on which the whole Head turns, and eparate them gently one from another, o that the firt Vertebra be till fatned to the Cranium, then Saw off
the upper part of the Cranium to take out the Brain, and with a lender piece of Wire a little hooked, trive to extract the Oicles of the Ears by the Foramen Auditorium, which will be more eaily extracted after a little boiling of the Cranium, o that by the ue of the aforeaid Wire they will come out; when they are extracted, keep them by themelves till you have occaion to ue them. Secondly, eparate the lat Vertebra of the Back from the firt of the Loins, and the Thighs from the Oa Innominata, and the Arms from the Scapula's, o you have all mot movable Parts eparated, Thirdly, eparate the Clavicle from the Scapula, and alo from where it's join'd to the firt Bone of the Sternon, and put them by themelves, always taking Care by ome mark to ditinguih the Right ide from the Left. Fourthly, divide the Cartilages from the bony Extremities of the Ribs in their very Coalition; then eparate every Rib from the Vertebrae of the Thorax, tying them one below another in order, in a piece of Packthread, to ditinguih them rightly, oberving alo always the ide they belong to; take Care in eparating them, they having a double Inertion, as well with the Bodies of the Vertebrae, as with their tranvere Procees. Fifthly, eparate every Vertebra of the Neck and Back one from another, hanging
them in order on a mall Cord, that you be not at a los in uniting them again when boil'd alo the Vertebra of the Loins in the ame order from the Os Sacrum; and divide the Oa Coccygis from that, and the Oa Innominata from the Os Sacrum, o that you may command, and cleane each in order more commodiouly. Sixthly, come to the Limbs, beginning firt with the Arms; as for Example, eparate the Os Humeri from the Cubitus, and that from the Carpus, which when you come to, take Care in eparating the Fleh and Tendons from them, that you may keep them as much as poible in their due places; for which end, I think it will not be amis to drill two or three holes quite through each rank, in which pas a Wire or two that will hold them in their right Situation, in time of boiling, they have in been before eparated from the Bones of the Metacarpus, which four Bones you mut alo eparate from each Finger, making ome fitting Marks with Thread, or the like, which utains one Finger, and which another; and as for the Fingers, put them in the Fingers of a Glove, according to order; o there will be les danger of Confuion; the Leg is to be eparated after the ame manner as the Arm, always making ome ditinguihing Character, which belongs to the Right ide, and which to the Left.

Some Bones require a longer time of boiling than others, Sternon, will not
dmit of boiling. and ome will not endure boiling at all, as the Sternon, with its annex'd Cartilages; the large Bones admit of longer boiling than the mall; now uppoe it be the Skeleton of a young Subject, boil not above an Hour, or an Hour and half at mot, let the Cartilaginous tips of the Bones come away; but in an Adult you may boil longer, the older the Subject is, the longer time is required in boiling; but before you put the long Bones into your boiling Veel, bore a hole in their Extremities, large enough, according to the bignes of the Bones, that the Medullar Parts may have free exit in boiling; to further which, run up the Bones o drill'd, a red hot Wire to and fro, to make a quicker dipatch of the fatty Particles, then cat them into your boiling Water; for it's this fatty Subtance only, which in many Skeletons makes them look o muddy and dull; when you think your Bones ufficiently boil'd, let them be preently taken out and cleaned one after another, a fat as you can; it's very good to rub the Bones with Maons Dut, which fetches off the Periostion, and levigates them very well; or you may wah them in boiling Lye made of Ahes, which cowers and cleanes them very well; after they are thus cleaned, throw them in clean cold Water, in which
let them lye about half a Day, then take them out, and wipe them dry, putting them till in the ame order as they were before you boiled them, and oberving to make the ame marks of ditinction; when they are thus dried, place them on the Leads of he Houe for ome Days and Nights, epecially when the Dews fall mot, but keep them from the violent heat of the Sun, that being apt to make them brittle; by this means they will become as white as Ivory.

The Sternon, The Sternon not to be boiled. as I have told you, is not to be boil'd at all, by reaon the Cartilages will hrink, and go out of their true Figure, o that you cannot bring the Cartilages to their true Shape, to be annex'd to the ends of the Ribs from whence they were eparated, which will make your Skeleton deform'd neither will it endure too great a heat in drying, o that you mut ue very great Caution in preparing it, which you may do thus, After you have Artificially and Neatly eparated it, as I have already taken notice of, cleane it as carefully from the Fleh as you can, then let it dry moderately in the hade, always triving to keep the Cartilages in their true Figure, and now and then picking away what you find of flehy Particles; when you think you have cleaned it well, rub it all over, epecially the Cartilages, with this
mixture, made of Wax, Roin, and Turpentine, ued very warm, for o you will hinder them from drying, and growing brittle, which they would be apt to do otherwie, and likewie defend them from the Worm and Moth, as alo from Corruption, o keep it whole by you till you have occaion to ue it, in making up your Skeleton.

When your Bones are thus clean'd and dry'd,Method of uniting your Skeleton. then begin to unite your Bones towards forming your Skeleton. Since the Spine is the prop of all, and the Os Sacrum the Bais of that, you ought to begin with it, as your Shipwrights do in making a Ship, who always begin with the Keel, to which they annex the other parts towards compleating the Veel; the Spine therefore may well be call'd the Keel of Man's Body, to which the ret of the Bones of the Skeleton are join'd.

Firt, Therefore prepare a fitting Rod of Steel, o order'd that it may have an Elatic Property, that is, when you bend it, to return to its firt Figure of treightnes; let it not be too thick, yet trong enough to upport all the Vertebrae; for by this means you will have the Spine perform all its motions. It mut be a little more than three Foot long, that it may pas through all the Vertebrae, and come out of
the top of the Cranium, to hang the whole Skeleton on; it mut be maller towards its top than bottom, by reaon the Bones of the Vertebra grow les towards the uperior part of the Spine; then Drill a hole in the very Body of the Os Sacrum, through which pas your Steel Wire, which you mut Artificially faten at the lower end of the Os Sacrum, to utain all the ret, then pas on the ame Wire the ret of the five Bones of the Loins, according to their order, holes being Drill'd through the very Bodies of all the Vertebra in the very Centre, that they may fit exactly each other; in the ame manner pas on the twelve Vertebrae of the Thorax, one by one, to which join the Ribs likewie in order, beginning with the lowet; this unition mut be made with Bras Wire, as well to the Bodies of each Vertebra as tranvere Procees, then pas on the Steel Wire to the Vertebrae of the Neck in their order, except the lat, which is call'd the Atlas, which mut be join'd to the Condiloid Procees of the Occipital Bone, by two fitting Bras Wires, o that the Head may have its due flexion and extention; this being done pas the Steel Rod through the Medullar Foramen of the Atlas, into the very Capacity of the Cranium, to pas through a hole Drill'd on the top, that the Head and Spine may hang regular, o the Head will have its Circular
motion, as well as flexion and extention, that being perform'd by the firt and econd Vertebra of the Neck, as this by the firt only, being join'd by a double Arthrodia to the Os Occipitis; when you have o done, unite the lower Jaw by its Condiloid Procees into the Glenoid Sinues of the Oa Petroa; then faten the Teeth in their proper Alveoli, with a preparation of Roin and Wax; then in its place hang the Os Hyoides, alo at the outward part of the Foramina Auditoria hang the Officles of the Ear in order; when you have done this, faten the Sternon and its Cartilages to the Ribs, holes being Artificially Drill'd through their Extremities, to faten them with Bras Wire; then faten the Clavicula to the Sternon, to which unite the Scapula, which is not only to be fatned with its Acromium to the Clavicula, but alo to the Body of the Ribs, to which its flat ide lyes on, then pas to the inferior part of the Spine, and faten trongly the Oa Innominata to the ides of the Os Sacrum, o as to be join'd even before at the Oa Pubis, which mut be join'd together with Wires, o the Pelvis, will be form'd, and to the Extremity of the Os Sacrum, faten the Oa Coccygis, and o you will have the Trunk with the Head extraordinary well fitted.

Then pas to the Limbs; firt take the Os Humeri, to whoe lower Extremity unite the Vlna by two Hooks, one fitly adapted to receive the other, which Hooks mut be fatned one in the Extremity of each Bone, o as the Bones it cloe one to another, for which end you may hollow a little the Extremity of the Humerus with a Graver, to make the Junctures the cloer; then to the ide of the Ulna faten the Radius, o that it may have its Prone and Supine motion, which may be done thus, Encompas its Neck pretty cloe with a Ring of Bras Wire, (after the ame manner as the Ligamentum Admirabile doth, which comes from the Ulna) which you mut faten in the lateral Sinus of the Head of the Ulnae; then adapt fitly, and in their due order, the Bones of the Carpus, and they having but little, or very obcure motion, you may only faten them by their ides with Bras Wire, holes being firt Drill'd through their very middle, alo faten the firt rank to the other according to Art; when the Carpus is thus form'd, unite the Bones of the Metacarp to them in their due order; for which end, you mut have four little Bras Hooks, fitted cloe in the Bones of the Carpus, to receive in order four other little Hooks, one in each Bone of the Metacarp, to be engaged in the four firt Hooks, faten them o as the Bones
may touch cloe, and yet at the ame time, the Juncture to have its proper motions; alo faten the ides of the Metacarp one to another with a piece of Bras Wire, yet o as the proper ditance be kept where it ought; then faten the firt Phalanx of the Bones of the Fingers to the Metacarpus, then the econd, and then the third, all in their due place, which mut be fatned with fitting Hooks, as in the Bones of the Metacarp with the Carpus; latly, join the Carpus to the Radius and Vlna, o that it may have its proper motions: When you have thus finihed the whole Limb, then faten it to the Trunk, but o as you may take it off when you pleae, which may be done by only fatening a Hook on the very Head of the Os Humerus, jut where its Ligament is, which is to be hung on a curved Bras Wire, which mut be fatned in the Cavity of the Scapula; the lower Extremity mut be managed after the ame manner, oberving fitting Circumtances, which mut be alo made to take off and on, as occaion requires.
I only deign'd this Appendix as a hint towards the forming of a Skeleton, which cannot be o well expret by Writing, as by often Working, and eeing it done.
